exclusive.notes: among us - The word "us" in this phrase may or may not exclude Theophilus.
handed them to us - The "us" in this phrase does not include Theophilus.

exclusive.quote: And what about us? What must we do?
exclusive.notes: And what about us? What must we do? - "How about us soldiers, what must we do?" John is not included in the words "us" and "we." The soldiers have implied that John had told the crowd and the tax collector what they must do and want to know what they as soldiers are to do.

exclusive.quote: Even the dust from your city that clings to our feet we wipe off against you!
exclusive.notes: Even the dust from your city that clings to our feet we wipe off against you! - Since Jesus was sending these people out in groups of two, it would be two people saying this. So languages that have a dual form of 'we' would use it. AT: "Just as you rejected us, we thoroughly reject you. We even reject the dust from your city that clings to our feet."

exclusive.quote: you want us to make preparations
exclusive.notes: you want us to make preparations - The word "us" does not include Jesus. Jesus would not be part of the group that would prepare the meal.

exclusive.quote: he sent him back to us
exclusive.notes: he sent him back to us - "Herod sent Jesus to return to us." The word "us" refers to Pilate and his soldiers, not to the priests and scribes who had gone to Herod with Jesus, nor to the crowd.

explicit.notes: servants of the message - You may need to specify what the message is. AT: "had served God by telling people his message" or "had taught people the good news about Jesus"
division - It is understood that this refers to the priests. AT: "division of priests" or "group of priests."

explicit.quote: His wife was from the daughters of Aaron
explicit.notes: His wife was from the daughters of Aaron - "His wife was descended from Aaron." This means she was from the same line of priests as Zechariah. AT: "His wife was also descended from Aaron" or "Zechariah and his wife Elizabeth were both descended from Aaron."
outside - The courtyard was the enclosed area surrounding the temple. AT: "outside the temple building" or "in the courtyard outside the temple."

your prayer has been heard - "God has heard what you asked." The following is implied and could be added: "and will grant it." God did not just hear what Zechariah prayed for; he was also going to do it.
make ready for the Lord - It is not stated how they will be ready. This implied information could be added. AT: "make ready to believe the Lord's message" or "make ready to obey the Lord."
in her sixth month - "in the sixth month of Elizabeth's pregnancy." It may be necessary to state this clearly if it would be confused with the sixth month of the year.
She went - It is implied that Mary finished her journey before she went in to Zechariah's house. This could be stated clearly. AT: "When she arrived, she went."
to circumcise the child - This was often a ceremony where one person circumcised the baby and friends were there to celebrate with the family. AT: "for the baby's circumcision ceremony."

explicit.quote: His father asked for a writing tablet
explicit.notes: His father asked for a writing tablet - It may be helpful to state how Zechariah "asked," since he could not speak. AT: "His father used his hands to show the people that he wanted them to give him a writing tablet"

the God of Israel - "Israel" here refers to the nation of Israel. The relationship between God and Israel could be stated more directly. AT: "the God who reigns over Israel" or "the God whom Israel worships."

explicit.quote: spoke by the mouth of his holy prophets
explicit.notes: spoke by the mouth of his holy prophets - God enabled the prophets to speak the words he wanted them to speak. God's control can the stated. AT: "caused his holy prophets to say."

explicit.quote: because of the tender mercy of our God
explicit.notes: because of the tender mercy of our God - It might be helpful to state that God's mercy helps people. AT: "because God is compassionate and merciful to us."
his own town - It may be helpful to state that "his own" does not refer to the town where he lived. AT: "the town in which his ancestors lived."

explicit.quote: wrapped him snugly in strips of cloth
explicit.notes: wrapped him snugly in strips of cloth - This was the normal way that mothers protected and cared for their babies in that culture. You could state this clearly. AT: "wrapped a warm blanket firmly around him" or "wrapped him comfortably in a blanket."
for their purification - "for them to become ceremonially clean." You could also state that God's role. AT: "for God to consider them to be clean again."
comforter of Israel - It is another name for the "Messiah" or "Christ." AT: "the one who would comfort Israel."
into the temple - "into the temple courtyard." Only priests could enter the temple building.
for revelation - It be necessary to state what is to be revealed. AT: "that will reveal God's truth."
was also there - Only priests could enter the temple. AT: "was also there in the temple courtyard"
in the temple - This refers to the courtyard around the temple. Only the priests were allowed in the temple. AT: "in the temple courtyard" or "at the temple."

explicit.quote: We have Abraham for our father
explicit.notes: We have Abraham for our father - "Abraham is our ancestor" or "We are Abraham's descendants." If it is unclear why they would say this, you may also add the implied information: "So God won't punish us."

John answered by saying - John's answer about a greater person coming clearly implies that John is not the Christ. It may be helpful to state this clearly for your audience, as the UDB does: "No, I am not."

explicit.quote: for marrying his brother's wife, Herodias
explicit.notes: for marrying his brother's wife, Herodias - "because Herod married Herodias, his own brother's wife" This was evil because Herod's brother was still alive. This can be stated clearly. AT: "because he married his brother's wife, Herodias, while his brother was still alive."

Jesus answered him - Jesus' rejection of the devil's challenge is clearly implied in his answer. It may be helpful to state this clearly for your audience, as the UDB does: "Jesus replied, 'No, I will not do that.'"

But Jesus answered...It is written - This contrast implies that Jesus refused to do what the devil asked. It may be helpful to state this clearly for your audience. AT: "But Jesus replied, 'No, I will not worship you, because it is written'"

But Jesus answered...It is written - This contrast implies that Jesus refused to do what the devil asked. It may be helpful to state this clearly for your audience. AT: "But Jesus replied, 'No, I will not worship you, because it is written'"

For it is written - The devil implies that his quote from the Psalms means Jesus will not be hurt if he is the Son of God. This could be stated clearly, as the UDB does: AT: "You will not be hurt, because it is written"
Jesus answering said to him - Jesus refuses to obey the devil, answering him with scripture. This refusal can be stated clearly. AT: "But Jesus replied, 'No, I will not do that'"
had finished tempting Jesus - This does not imply that the devil was successful in his temptationâ€”Jesus resisted every attempt. This can be stated clearly. AT: "had finished trying to tempt Jesus"

during Elijah's time - The people to whom Jesus was speaking would have known that Elijah was one of God's prophets. If your readers would not know that, you can make this implicit information explicit as in the UDB. AT: "when Elijah was prophesying in Israel."

a widow living in Zarephath - The people living in the town of Zarephath were Gentiles, not Jews. The people listening to Jesus would have understood that the people of Zarephath were Gentiles. AT: "a Gentile widow living in Zarephath."

explicit.quote: pleaded with him on her behalf
explicit.notes: pleaded with him on her behalf - This means they asked Jesus to heal her from the fever. This can be stated clearly. AT: "asked Jesus to heal her from the fever" or "asked Jesus to cure her fever."
rebuked the fever - "spoke sternly to the fever" or "commanded the fever to leave her"
Demons also came out - It is implied that Jesus made the demons leave the demon-possessed people. This can be stated clearly. AT: "Jesus also forced demons to come out."
they began to sink - "the boats began to sink." The reason could be stated clearly. AT: "the boats began to sink because the fish were so heavy."
you can make me clean - It is understood that he was asking Jesus to heal him. This could be stated clearly. AT: "please make me clean, because you are able."

make me clean...Be clean - This refers to ceremonial cleanness, but it is understood that he is unclean because of the leprosy. He is really asking Jesus to heal him of his disease. This can be stated clearly. AT: "heal me from leprosy so I will be clean...Be healed."

make me clean...Be clean - This refers to ceremonial cleanness, but it is understood that he is unclean because of the leprosy. He is really asking Jesus to heal him of his disease. This can be stated clearly. AT: "heal me from leprosy so I will be clean...Be healed."

explicit.quote: they went up to the housetop
explicit.notes: they went up to the housetop - Houses had flat roofs, and some houses had a ladder or staircase outside to make it easy to go up there. This could be stated. AT: "they went up to the flat roof of the house."

explicit.quote: Who can forgive sins, but God alone?
explicit.notes: Who can forgive sins, but God alone? - The implied information is that if a person claims to forgive sins he says he is God. This could be written as a clear statement. AT: "No one can forgive sins but God alone" or "God is the only one who can forgive sins."
reclining at the table - The Greek style of eating at a feast was to lie on a couch and prop oneself up with the left arm on some pillows. AT: "eat together" or "eat at the table."

explicit.quote: you eat and drink with...sinful people
explicit.notes: you eat and drink with...sinful people - The Pharisees and scribes believed that religious people should separate themselves from people they considered to be sinners. The word "you" is plural.

explicit.quote: you eat and drink with...sinful people
explicit.notes: you eat and drink with...sinful people - The Pharisees and scribes believed that religious people should separate themselves from people they considered to be sinners. The word "you" is plural.

explicit.quote: the wedding attendants of the bridegroom fast
explicit.notes: the wedding attendants of the bridegroom fast - Fasting is a sign of sadness. The religious leaders understood that the wedding attendants would not fast while the bridegroom was with them.

explicit.quote: the new wine would burst the skins
explicit.notes: the new wine would burst the skins - When the new wine ferments and expands, it breaks the old skins because they can no longer stretch out. Jesus' audience would have understood the information about the wine's fermenting and expanding.
he says, 'The old is better.' - It may be helpful to add: "and is therefore not willing to try the new wine."
rubbing them between their hands - They did this to separate the grain seeds. This could be stated clearly. AT: "They rubbed them in their hands to separate the grains from the husks"
doing something - The Pharisees considered even the small action of rubbing a handful of grain to be unlawful work. This could be stated clearly. AT: "doing work"
doing something wrong - The Jewish leaders incorrectly considered almost any action on the Sabbath to be "work." This could be stated. AT: "disobeying their laws about not working on the Sabbath"

explicit.quote: The names of the apostles were
explicit.notes: The names of the apostles were - This is implied information added to the ULB text.
became a traitor - It may be necessary to explain what "traitor" means in this context. AT: "betrayed his friend" or "turned his friend over to enemies"

explicit.quote: receive the same amount back again
explicit.notes: receive the same amount back again - The law of Moses commanded the Jews not to receive interest on money they loaned to each other.

explicit.quote: built the house's foundation on solid rock
explicit.notes: built the house's foundation on solid rock - "dug the foundation of the house deep enough to reach a foundation of solid rock." Some cultures may not be familiar with building on bedrock, and may need to use another image for a stable foundation.

explicit.quote: on top of the ground without a foundation
explicit.notes: on top of the ground without a foundation - Some cultures may not know that a house with a foundation is stronger. Additional information may be helpful. AT: "but he did not dig down and build first a foundation."

explicit.quote: not even in Israel have I found anyone with so much faith
explicit.notes: not even in Israel have I found anyone with so much faith - The implication is that Jesus expected Jewish people to have this kind of faith, but they didn't. He did not expect Gentiles to have this kind of faith, yet this man did. You may need to add this implied information. AT: "I have not found any Israelite who trusts me as much as this Gentile does!"

explicit.quote: he who is forgiven only a little
explicit.notes: he who is forgiven only a little - "anyone who is forgiven little." In this sentence Jesus states a general principle. However, Simon was expected to understand that Jesus was saying that Simon had loved little.

explicit.quote: You have been given the privilege of understanding
explicit.notes: You have been given the privilege of understanding - AT: "God has given you the gift of understanding" or "God has made you able to understand"
how you listen - AT: "how you listen to what I tell you" or "how you listen to God's word"
they were afraid - "they were afraid of Jesus"
But as he was going - Some translators may need to first say, "So Jesus agreed to go with the man."

explicit.quote: the crowds of people were pressing up against him
explicit.notes: the crowds of people were pressing up against him - "the people were crowding tightly around Jesus"

explicit.quote: the crowds of people are pressing in on you and crowding you
explicit.notes: the crowds of people are pressing in on you and crowding you - By saying this, Peter was implying that anyone could have touched Jesus. This implicit information can be made explicit if necessary as in the UDB.
I beheaded John - AT: "I commanded my soldiers to cut off John's head"

explicit.quote: they did not understand what this statement meant
explicit.notes: they did not understand what this statement meant - AT: "they did not know he was talking about his death"

explicit.quote: command fire to come down from heaven and destroy them
explicit.notes: command fire to come down from heaven and destroy them - James and John suggested this method of judgment because they knew that this was how the prophets such as Elijah had judged people who rejected God.

explicit.quote: Foxes have holes...nowhere to lay his head
explicit.notes: Foxes have holes...nowhere to lay his head - Jesus responds with a proverb to teach the man about being Jesus' disciple. Jesus implies that if the man were to follow him, that man too might not have a home. AT: "Foxes have holes...nowhere to lay his head. So do not expect that you will have a home."

explicit.quote: Foxes have holes...nowhere to lay his head
explicit.notes: Foxes have holes...nowhere to lay his head - Jesus responds with a proverb to teach the man about being Jesus' disciple. Jesus implies that if the man were to follow him, that man too might not have a home. AT: "Foxes have holes...nowhere to lay his head. So do not expect that you will have a home."

explicit.quote: No one...fit for the kingdom of God
explicit.notes: No one...fit for the kingdom of God - Jesus responds with a proverb to teach the man about being his disciple. Jesus means that a person is not suitable for the kingdom go God if he focuses on people in his past instead of following Jesus.

explicit.quote: No one...fit for the kingdom of God
explicit.notes: No one...fit for the kingdom of God - Jesus responds with a proverb to teach the man about being his disciple. Jesus means that a person is not suitable for the kingdom go God if he focuses on people in his past instead of following Jesus.
the judgment day - The phrase simply says "that day." But the disciples would have understood that this refers to the time of final judgment of sinners.
The seventy returned - Some languages will need to say that the seventy actually went out first as the UDB does. This is implicit information that can be made explicit.

explicit.quote: over all the power of the enemy
explicit.notes: over all the power of the enemy - "I have given you authority to crush the power of the enemy" or "I have given you authority to defeat the enemy." The enemy is Satan.

explicit.quote: Turning to the disciples, he said privately
explicit.notes: Turning to the disciples, he said privately - This was possibly at a later time. AT: "Later, when his disciples were alone with him, he said"
Behold, a certain teacher - This event happens at a later time. AT: "One day as Jesus was teaching people, a certain teacher."

and when he saw him - "and when the priest saw the injured man." A priest is a very religious person, so the audience would assume that he would help the injured man. Since he did not, this phrase could be translated as "but when he saw him" to call attention to this unexpected result.

explicit.quote: he passed by on the other side
explicit.notes: he passed by on the other side - It is implied that he did not help the man. AT: "he did not help the injured man but instead walked past him on the other side of the road."

ask...seek...knock - Jesus gave these commands to encourage his disciples to pray continually. Some languages may also require more information with these verbs. Use the form of "you" that would be most appropriate in this context. AT: "keep asking for what you need...keep seeking what you need from God...keep knocking on the door."

ask...seek...knock - Jesus gave these commands to encourage his disciples to pray continually. Some languages may also require more information with these verbs. Use the form of "you" that would be most appropriate in this context. AT: "keep asking for what you need...keep seeking what you need from God...keep knocking on the door."

ask...seek...knock - Jesus gave these commands to encourage his disciples to pray continually. Some languages may also require more information with these verbs. Use the form of "you" that would be most appropriate in this context. AT: "keep asking for what you need...keep seeking what you need from God...keep knocking on the door."

it was mute - It is unlikely that the demon could not speak. The readers would have probably understood that this demon had power to prevent people from speaking. AT: "the demon caused the man to be unable to speak."

explicit.quote: when the demon had come out
explicit.notes: when the demon had come out - "when the demon came out of the man" or "when the demon left the man"

explicit.quote: For you say I cast out demons by Beelzebul
explicit.notes: For you say I cast out demons by Beelzebul - "For you say that it is by the power of Beelzebul that I make demons leave people." The next part of his argument can be stated explicitly: "that would mean that Satan is divided against himself."

explicit.quote: by whom do your followers drive them out
explicit.notes: by whom do your followers drive them out - "by whose power do your followers force demons to leave people." Jesus uses a question to teach the people. The meaning of Jesus' question can be made explicit. AT: "then we must agree that your followers also drive out demons by Beelzebul's power. But we know that that is not true."
It seeks a sign - "They want me to give them a sign" or "Many of you want me to give you a sign." The information about what kind of sign they wanted can be made explicit as in the UDB.

explicit.quote: someone greater than Solomon is here
explicit.notes: someone greater than Solomon is here - Jesus is speaking about himself. AT: "I am greater than Solomon but you have not listened to me."

explicit.quote: someone greater than Jonah is here
explicit.notes: someone greater than Jonah is here - Jesus is speaking about himself. AT: "I am greater than Jonah but you have not repented."
wash - The Pharisees had a rule that people must wash their hands in order to be ceremonially clean before God. AT: "wash his hands" or "wash his hands in order to be ritually clean."

explicit.quote: So you are witnesses and consent
explicit.notes: So you are witnesses and consent - Jesus is rebuking the Pharisees and teachers of the law. They knew about the murder of the prophets, but did not condemn their ancestors for killing them. AT: "So, rather than denouncing them, you are witnesses and consent."

explicit.quote: he will tuck his long robe in his belt
explicit.notes: he will tuck his long robe in his belt - AT: "he will prepare to serve them by tucking his clothes into his belt" or "he will dress to serve"

explicit.quote: whose blood Pilate mixed with their own sacrifices
explicit.notes: whose blood Pilate mixed with their own sacrifices - Here "blood" refers to the death of the Galileans. Pilate probably ordered his soldiers to kill people rather than doing it himself. AT: "whom Pilate's soldiers killed while the Galileans were offering sacrifices."
It is like yeast - Only a little bit of yeast was needed to make a lot of dough rise. This can be made clear as it is in the UDB.

the narrow door - Jesus represents entering the kingdom of God as entering a narrow door. The fact that the door is narrow implies that only a few people at a time can go through it. Translate it in a way to keep this restrictive meaning.
five pairs of oxen - AT: "10 oxen to work in my fields"

The servant said - It may be necessary to state clearly the implied information that the servant did what the master commanded him. AT: "After the servant went out and did that, he came back and said."
and kill it - The implied information that they were to cook the meat can be made clear. AT: "and kill it and cook it."
John came - AT: "John the Baptist came and preached"

explicit.quote: for fear that they also come
explicit.notes: for fear that they also come - It is implied that the way they would avoid going there is by repenting. AT: "and they might repent and not come."
this place of torment - AT: "this place where we suffer torment" or "this place where we suffer terrible pain"

explicit.quote: If you had faith as a mustard seed
explicit.notes: If you had faith as a mustard seed - A "mustard seed" is a very small seed. Jesus implies that they did not have even a small amount of faith. AT: "If you had faith that was even as small as mustard seed" or "If only your faith was as big as a mustard seed, but it isn't."
have mercy on us - AT: "please show us mercy by healing us"
show yourselves to the priests - AT: "show yourselves to the priests so they can examine you"

explicit.quote: After the same manner it will be
explicit.notes: After the same manner it will be - "It will be like that." AT: "In the same way people will not be ready."
return - They were not to go back to the house to get anything. They were to flee quickly.

explicit.quote: to receive for himself a kingdom
explicit.notes: to receive for himself a kingdom - This is the image of a lesser king going to a greater king. The greater king would give the lesser king the right and authority to rule over his own country.

if these were silent - This is a hypothetical situation. Some translators may need to make it clear what Jesus was implying when he said this: "No, I will not rebuke them, for if these people were to be silent."

If only you had known - This is an exclamation. Jesus was expressing his sadness that the people of Jerusalem did not know these things. The implied information can be added to the end of the sentence: "then you could have had peace." AT: "I wish so much that you knew or "I am very sad because you do not know."

explicit.quote: they were afraid of the people
explicit.notes: they were afraid of the people - This is the reason that they did not arrest Jesus right away. The people respected Jesus, and the religious leaders were afraid of what the people might do if they arrested him. AT: "But they did not arrest him because they were afraid of the people."

explicit.quote: to the rule and to the authority of the governor
explicit.notes: to the rule and to the authority of the governor - "Rule" and "authority" are two ways of saying the same thing. It can be translated with one or both expressions. AT: "so that the governor would punish Jesus."
but of the living - AT: "but the God of living people" or "the God of people whose spirits are alive, even though their bodies may have died."
Some of the scribes answered - "Some of the scribes said to Jesus." There were scribes present when the Sadducees were questioning Jesus.

explicit.quote: they did not dare ask him
explicit.notes: they did not dare ask him - "they were afraid to ask him" or "they did not risk asking him." The implied information about the purpose of the questions and their reason for not asking can be made explicit. AT: "They did ask him any more tricky questions because they feared that his wise answers would make them appear foolish again."
wrath to this people - "there will be wrath to this people." AT: "this people will experience God's anger" or "God will be very angry and will punish this people."
summer is already near - "summer is about to start." Summer in Israel is very dry, so crops are harvested at the beginning of summer. AT: "harvest time is ready to start."

explicit.quote: For that day will come on you suddenly
explicit.notes: For that day will come on you suddenly - Some may need to add the implicit information: "For if you are not careful, that day will come on you suddenly." The coming of the day will appear to be sudden and unexpected to those who are not ready and watching for it.
he is a Galilean - The man could probably tell Peter was from Galilee from the way he talked.
Prophesy! - "Speak words from God!" The implied information is that God would have to tell Jesus who struck him since Jesus was blindfolded and could not see.

explicit.quote: Then you are the Son of God?
explicit.notes: Then you are the Son of God? - The Council asked this question because they wanted Jesus to explicitly confirm their understanding that he was saying he was the Son of God. AT: "So when you said that, did you mean that you are the Son of God?"
he was under Herod's authority - The passage does not state the implied fact that Herod was the ruler of Galilee. AT: "Jesus was under the authority of Herod because Herod ruled over Galilee."
Away with this man - "Take this man away!" AT: "Take this man away and execute him!"
prepared spices and ointments - AT: "prepared spices and ointments to prepare Jesus' body for burial"
who would free Israel - The Romans ruled over the Jews. AT: "who would free the Israelites from our Roman enemies."

idiom.notes: before God - "in God's sight" or "in God's opinion"
before the face of - The "face of" is here an idiom that refers to the Lord's presence. It is sometimes omitted in translation. AT: "before."
looked at me with favor - "to look at" is an idiom that means "to treat" or "to deal with." AT: "regarded me kindly" or "had pity on me"
The Lord is with you - "with you" is an idiom that implies support and acceptance. AT: "The Lord is pleased with you."
arose - This idiom means she not only stood up, but also "got ready." AT: "started out" or "got ready"
raised her voice - This idiom means "increased the volume of her voice."
Blessed are you among women - The idiom "among women" means "more than any other woman."
came to my ears - This idiom means "I heard."
thoughts of their hearts - "heart" is an idiom that refers to a person's inner thoughts. AT: "thoughts in their inner being."
to remember - God cannot forget. When God "remembers," it is an idiom that means God acts upon his earlier promise.
by the mouth of - This idiom means "my means of" or "through the voices of."
before him - "in his presence"

idiom.quote: go before the face of the Lord
idiom.notes: go before the face of the Lord - This idiom means "go ahead of the Lord" or "come before the Lord."
sent out a decree ordering - They idiom means he gave an order or a command. AT: "ordered" or "gave a command."

idiom.quote: Every male that opens the womb
idiom.notes: Every male that opens the womb - "open the womb" is an idiom that refers to the first baby coming out of the womb. This referred to both animals and people. AT: "Every firstborn offspring that is a male" or "Every firstborn son."
very advanced in years - This idiom means "very old."

idiom.quote: treasured all these things in her heart
idiom.notes: treasured all these things in her heart - "carefully remembered all these things" or "joyfully thought about all these things." The words "treasured" and "heart" indicate that Mary considered these things to be very deeply personal and important.
wondering in their hearts - This idiom means "seriously wondering."

idiom.quote: to thoroughly clear off his threshing floor
idiom.notes: to thoroughly clear off his threshing floor - The threshing floor is the place where wheat was stacked in preparation for threshing. To "clear off" the floor is an idiom that means to finish threshing the grain. AT: "to finish threshing his grain."
were fixed on him - This idiom means "were focused on him" or "were looking intently at him."
in your hearing - This idiom means "while you are listening to me."

idiom.quote: he cried out with a loud voice
idiom.notes: he cried out with a loud voice - "he shouted loudly." Some languages have an idiom for this like the English idiom, "he shouted at the top of his lungs."

idiom.quote: What do we have to do with you
idiom.notes: What do we have to do with you - This belligerent response is an idiom that means: "What do we have in common?" or "What right to you have to bother us?"
was suffering with - This is an idiom that means "was sick with."
in your hearts - "inside yourselves." This refers to the part of a person that thinks or believes.
Follow me - To "follow" someone was a term that means to become their disciple. AT: "Be my disciple" or "Come, follow me as your teacher."
leap for joy - This idiom means "be extremely joyful."
Bless those - God is the one who blesses. This idiom could be rewritten. AT: "Ask God to bless those"

idiom.quote: in the hearing of the people
idiom.notes: in the hearing of the people - The idiom "in the hearing" emphasizes that he wanted them to hear what he said. AT: "to the people who were listening to him" or "to the people who were present" or "for the people to hear."
enter under my roof - This phrase is an idiom that means "come into my house." If your language has an idiom that means "come into my house," think about whether it would be good to use here.
just say a word - The servant understood that Jesus could heal the servant just by speaking. AT: "just give the order."
looked upon - This idiom means "cared for."
were satisfied - AT: "they had as much as they wanted to eat"

idiom.quote: will not taste death until they see the kingdom of God
idiom.notes: will not taste death until they see the kingdom of God - AT: "will see the kingdom of God before they die" or "will see the kingdom of God before you die"

idiom.quote: Let these words go deeply into your ears
idiom.notes: Let these words go deeply into your ears - AT: "Listen carefully and remember" or "Do not forget this"
set his face - AT: "made up his mind" or "decided"

idiom.quote: Leave the dead to bury their own dead
idiom.notes: Leave the dead to bury their own dead - Since people who are dead cannot bury anyone, the implied meaning here is to let the spiritually dead people bury the physically dead people.

idiom.quote: having put his hand to the plow
idiom.notes: having put his hand to the plow - AT: "having started to plow his field" or "having started to prepare his field"

idiom.quote: she came from the ends of the earth
idiom.notes: she came from the ends of the earth - AT: "she came a very great distance" or "she came from a place very far away"

idiom.quote: He who has ears to hear, let him hear
idiom.notes: He who has ears to hear, let him hear - AT: "If you have ears to hear, listen well" or "If you hear what I am saying, pay attention"
came to himself - AT: "came to his senses" or "understood his situation"

idiom.quote: he yearned to be fed with what fell from the rich man's table
idiom.notes: he yearned to be fed with what fell from the rich man's table - AT: "he wished for the rich man to give him his extra food that he threw away"
he lifted up his eyes - AT: "he looked up"
they lifted up their voices - AT: "they called with a loud voice" or "they called aloud"

idiom.quote: lift up his eyes to heaven
idiom.notes: lift up his eyes to heaven - AT: "look toward heaven" or "look upward"

idiom.quote: sought to lay hands on him
idiom.notes: sought to lay hands on him - AT: "looked for a way to arrest Jesus"
lift up your heads - AT: "look up." By looking up, they would be able to see their rescuer coming to them.

idiom.quote: on the face of the whole earth
idiom.notes: on the face of the whole earth - AT: "on the surface of the whole earth" or "on the entire earth"
about a stone's throw - "about the distance that someone can throw a stone." AT: "a short distance" or with an estimated measurement like "about 30 meters"
lay your hands on me - AT: "arrest me"

idiom.quote: I do not know what you are saying
idiom.notes: I do not know what you are saying - AT: "what you said is not true at all" or "what you said is completely false"
You say so - AT: "What you said is correct" or "It is just as you have asked me"
rose up - This is an idiom that means "began to act." Whether Peter was sitting or standing when he decided to act is not important. AT: "started out."

idiom.quote: Then he opened their minds, that they might understand the scriptures
idiom.notes: Then he opened their minds, that they might understand the scriptures - AT: "Then he enabled them to understand the scriptures"

metaphor.quote: walked blamelessly in
metaphor.notes: walked blamelessly in - "walk" is a metaphor for the way a person lives and acts. AT: "lived according to without blame" or "completely obeyed without fault."

metaphor.quote: fear fell on him
metaphor.notes: fear fell on him - Fear is described as something that attacked or overpowered Zechariah.

metaphor.quote: turn the hearts
metaphor.notes: turn the hearts - To "turn a heart" is a metaphor for changing someone's attitude toward something.

metaphor.quote: the disobedient will walk
metaphor.notes: the disobedient will walk - "walk" is a metaphor for the way a person lives and acts. AT: "the disobedient will act" or "the disobedient will live"

metaphor.quote: the fruit of your womb
metaphor.notes: the fruit of your womb - Mary's baby is compared to the fruit that a plant produces. AT: "the baby in your womb" or "the baby you will bear"

metaphor.quote: has raised up those of low condition
metaphor.notes: has raised up those of low condition - In this word picture, people who are important are higher than people who are less important. AT: "has made humble people important" or "has given honor to people whom others have not honored."

metaphor.quote: a horn of salvation for us
metaphor.notes: a horn of salvation for us - The horn of an animal is a symbol for its power to defend itself. This meaning could be stated clearly. AT: "someone with the power to save us."

metaphor.quote: the sunrise from on high...to shine on
metaphor.notes: the sunrise from on high...to shine on - Light is often a metaphor for truth. Here, the way a sunrise lights up the earth is used as an example of how the Savior will provide spiritual truth to people.

metaphor.quote: the sunrise from on high...to shine on
metaphor.notes: the sunrise from on high...to shine on - Light is often a metaphor for truth. Here, the way a sunrise lights up the earth is used as an example of how the Savior will provide spiritual truth to people.

metaphor.quote: them who sit in darkness
metaphor.notes: them who sit in darkness - Darkness is here a metaphor for people without the truth. AT: "people who do not know the truth"

metaphor.quote: in the shadow of death
metaphor.notes: in the shadow of death - The shadow is a metaphor for something that is approaching. Here, it refers to their spiritual darkness which will cause them to die. AT: "who are about to die."

metaphor.quote: guide our feet
metaphor.notes: guide our feet - Guiding the walk of a person is a metaphor for guiding their spiritual understanding. AT: "guide us" or "teach us."

metaphor.quote: into the path of peace
metaphor.notes: into the path of peace - "the path of peace" is a metaphor for the way of life that causes a person to have peace with God. AT: "to live a peaceful life" or "to walk along a path that leads to peace."

metaphor.quote: a large number of the heavenly army
metaphor.notes: a large number of the heavenly army - The word "heavenly army" here could refer to a literal army of angels, or it could be a metaphor for an organized group of angels. AT: "a large group of angels from heaven"

metaphor.quote: treasuring them in her heart
metaphor.notes: treasuring them in her heart - A treasure is something that is very valuable or precious. Mary considered the things she was told about her son to be very precious. AT: "carefully remembering them" or "joyfully remembering them."

metaphor.quote: He is light
metaphor.notes: He is light - This metaphor means that the child will help people to see and understand the say way light helps people see accurately. AT: "this child will enable people to understand as light allows people to see accurately."

metaphor.quote: a sword will pierce your own soul
metaphor.notes: a sword will pierce your own soul - This metaphor describes the deep sadness that Mary would feel. AT: "Your sadness will be painful as though a sword pierced your heart."

metaphor.quote: Make ready the way of the Lord
metaphor.notes: Make ready the way of the Lord - This word picture of a road means, "Repent and be ready for when the Lord comes."

metaphor.quote: make his paths straight
metaphor.notes: make his paths straight - This image of a path is also a word picture that means, "be continuously ready for the Lord to come."

metaphor.quote: Every valley will be filled...every mountain and hill will be made level
metaphor.notes: Every valley will be filled...every mountain and hill will be made level - When people prepare the road for an important person who is coming, they cut down the high places and fill in the low places so that the road will be level. This is part of the metaphor started in the previous verse.

metaphor.quote: Every valley will be filled...every mountain and hill will be made level
metaphor.notes: Every valley will be filled...every mountain and hill will be made level - When people prepare the road for an important person who is coming, they cut down the high places and fill in the low places so that the road will be level. This is part of the metaphor started in the previous verse.

metaphor.quote: You offspring of poisonous snakes
metaphor.notes: You offspring of poisonous snakes - In this metaphor, poisonous snakes are dangerous and represent evil. AT: "You evil poisonous snakes!" or "You are evil like poisonous snakes."

metaphor.quote: Produce fruits that are worthy of repentance
metaphor.notes: Produce fruits that are worthy of repentance - In this metaphor, a person's behavior is compared to fruit. Just as a plant is expected to produce fruit that is appropriate for that kind of plant, a person who says that he has repented is expected to live righteously. AT: "Produce the kind of fruit that shows that you have repented" or "Do the good things that show that you have turned away from your sin."

metaphor.quote: the ax has been placed against the root of the trees
metaphor.notes: the ax has been placed against the root of the trees - The ax that is ready to cut the roots of a tree is a metaphor for the punishment is about to start. It can also be stated in active form. AT: "God is like the man who has placed his ax against the root of the trees."

metaphor.quote: every tree that does not produce good fruit is chopped down
metaphor.notes: every tree that does not produce good fruit is chopped down - This can be stated in active form. AT: "He chops down every tree that does not produce good fruit."

metaphor.quote: thrown into the fire
metaphor.notes: thrown into the fire - "fire" is also a metaphor for punishment. This can be stated in active form. AT: "throws it into the fire"

metaphor.quote: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire
metaphor.notes: He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit and with fire - This metaphor compares literal baptism that brings a person into contact with water to a spiritual baptism that brings them into contact with the Holy Spirit and with fire.

metaphor.quote: fire
metaphor.notes: fire - Here the word "fire" may refers to 1) judgment or 2) purification. It is preferred to leave it as "fire."

metaphor.quote: His winnowing fork is in his hand
metaphor.notes: His winnowing fork is in his hand - A farmer who is ready to separate wheat grain from chaff is a metaphor for Christ who is ready to judge people. AT: "He is holding a winnowing fork because he is ready."

metaphor.quote: he anointed me
metaphor.notes: he anointed me - In the Old Testament, ceremonial oil was poured on a person when they were given power and authority to do a special task. Jesus uses this metaphor to refer to the Holy Spirit being on him to prepare him for this work. AT: "the Holy Spirit is upon me to empower me" or "the Holy Spirit gave me power and authority."

metaphor.quote: when the sky was shut up with no rain
metaphor.notes: when the sky was shut up with no rain - This is a metaphor. The sky is pictured as a ceiling that was closed up to keep the water above it from coming down as rain. AT: "when no rain came down from the sky" or "when there was no rain at all."

metaphor.quote: you will catch men
metaphor.notes: you will catch men - The image of catching fish is being used as a metaphor for gathering people to follow Christ. AT: "you will fish for people" or "you will gather people for me" or "you will bring people to be my disciples."

metaphor.quote: the bridegroom will be taken away from them
metaphor.notes: the bridegroom will be taken away from them - Jesus is comparing himself to the bridegroom, and the disciples to the wedding attendants. He did not explain the metaphor, so the translation should explain it only when necessary.

metaphor.quote: drinking old wine...desires new wine
metaphor.notes: drinking old wine...desires new wine - This metaphor contrasts the old teaching of the religious leaders against the new teaching of Jesus. The point is that people who is used to the old teaching are not willing to listen to the new things that Jesus is teaching.

metaphor.quote: drinking old wine...desires new wine
metaphor.notes: drinking old wine...desires new wine - This metaphor contrasts the old teaching of the religious leaders against the new teaching of Jesus. The point is that people who is used to the old teaching are not willing to listen to the new things that Jesus is teaching.

metaphor.quote: blind person
metaphor.notes: blind person - The person who is "blind" is a metaphor for a person who has not been taught as a disciple.

metaphor.quote: the tiny piece of straw that is in your brother's eye
metaphor.notes: the tiny piece of straw that is in your brother's eye - This is a metaphor that refers to the less important faults of a fellow believer.

metaphor.quote: the good treasure of his heart
metaphor.notes: the good treasure of his heart - "the good things he keeps in his heart" or "the good things he values"

metaphor.quote: brings out that which is good
metaphor.notes: brings out that which is good - Bringing out treasure is a metaphor for doing actions. This could be stated. AT: "lives his life and shows that which is good" or "does the things that are good."

metaphor.quote: the evil treasure of his heart
metaphor.notes: the evil treasure of his heart - "the evil things he keeps in his heart" or "the evil things he values"

metaphor.quote: a reed being shaken by the wind
metaphor.notes: a reed being shaken by the wind - Possible meanings of this metaphor are 1) a person who easily changes his mind, as reeds are easily moved by the wind, or 2) a person who talks a lot but does not say anything important, as reeds rattle when the wind blows.

metaphor.quote: among those born of women
metaphor.notes: among those born of women - "among those to whom a woman has given birth." This is a figure of speech referring to all people. AT: "of all the people who have ever lived."

metaphor.quote: takes away
metaphor.notes: takes away - In the parable this was a metaphor of a bird snatching away the seeds. Try to use words in your language that keep that image.

metaphor.quote: they become choked with the cares
metaphor.notes: they become choked with the cares - "the cares and riches and pleasures of this life choke them." AT: "as weeds prevent good plants from growing, the cares, riches, and pleasures of this life keep these people from becoming mature."

metaphor.quote: so they bring no fruit to maturity
metaphor.notes: so they bring no fruit to maturity - "they do not bear ripe fruit." AT: "so like a plant that does not become mature and bear fruit, they do not become mature and produce good works."

metaphor.quote: produce fruit with perseverance
metaphor.notes: produce fruit with perseverance - "produce fruit by persevering." AT: "like healthy plants that produce good fruit, they produce good works by persevering."

metaphor.quote: My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God, and obey it
metaphor.notes: My mother and my brothers are those who hear the word of God, and obey it - AT: "Those who hear the word of God and obey it are like a mother and brothers to me" or "Those who hear the word of God and obey it are as important to me as my mother and brothers"

metaphor.quote: take up his cross daily
metaphor.notes: take up his cross daily - "lift up his cross and carry it every day." This does not mean they must literally carry a cross every day. It means his followers must deny the things they want and be willing to suffer and even die to obey Jesus.

metaphor.quote: he also is receiving me
metaphor.notes: he also is receiving me - AT: "it is like he is receiving me"

metaphor.quote: The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few
metaphor.notes: The harvest is plentiful, but the laborers are few - "There is a big crop, but not enough workers to bring it in." Jesus means there are many people ready to enter God's kingdom, but there are not enough disciples to go teach and help the people.

metaphor.quote: authority to tread on serpents, and scorpions
metaphor.notes: authority to tread on serpents, and scorpions - "authority to step on snakes and crush scorpions." Possible meanings are 1) this refers to actual snakes and scorpions or 2) snakes and scorpions are a metaphor for evil spirits. The UDB translates this as referring to evil spirits: "I have given you the right to attack evil spirits."

metaphor.quote: knock
metaphor.notes: knock - To knock at a door is to hit it a few times to let a person inside the house know you are standing outside. It can also be translated using the way people in your culture show that they have arrived, such as "call out" or "cough" or "clap." Here, it means a person should keep praying to God until he answers.

metaphor.quote: falls
metaphor.notes: falls - "crashed down and is destroyed." This image of the house collapsing refers to the destruction of a family when the members fight each other.

metaphor.quote: When a strong man...man's possessions
metaphor.notes: When a strong man...man's possessions - This speaks about Jesus who is defeating Satan and his demons as a stronger man who takes what belongs to a strong man.

metaphor.quote: When a strong man...man's possessions
metaphor.notes: When a strong man...man's possessions - This speaks about Jesus who is defeating Satan and his demons as a stronger man who takes what belongs to a strong man.

metaphor.quote: my house from which I came
metaphor.notes: my house from which I came - This refers to the person he used to lived in. AT: "the person in whom I used to live!"

metaphor.quote: finds that house swept out and put in order
metaphor.notes: finds that house swept out and put in order - AT: "finds that someone has swept the house clean and put everything where it belongs" or "finds that the person is like a clean and organized house"

metaphor.quote: swept out
metaphor.notes: swept out - "empty." This metaphor refers to the condition of the person who did not fill their life with God's Spirit after the demon left.

metaphor.quote: when your eye is bad, your body is full of darkness
metaphor.notes: when your eye is bad, your body is full of darkness - Jesus speaks about falsehood as if it were darkness. AT: "when your vision is bad, your whole life is full of falsehood."

metaphor.quote: but the inside of you is filled with greed and evil
metaphor.notes: but the inside of you is filled with greed and evil - This compares the way they ignore the inside of the container to how they ignore their own internal condition.

metaphor.quote: you burden men with burdens hard to carry
metaphor.notes: you burden men with burdens hard to carry - "You put burdens on people that are heavy for them to carry." Jesus speaks about someone giving people many rules as if the person were giving them heavy things to carry. AT: "You burden people by giving them too many rules to follow."

metaphor.quote: but you do not even touch those burdens with one of your own fingers
metaphor.notes: but you do not even touch those burdens with one of your own fingers - "but you do not even use one of your fingers to help them carry the burdens." AT: "but you do not do anything at all to help them obey your rules."

metaphor.quote: you have taken away the key of knowledge...hinder those who are entering
metaphor.notes: you have taken away the key of knowledge...hinder those who are entering - Jesus speaks about God's truth as if it were in a house that the teachers refuse to enter and will not let other enter either. This means the teachers do not truly know God, and they prevent others from knowing him as well.

metaphor.quote: you have taken away the key of knowledge...hinder those who are entering
metaphor.notes: you have taken away the key of knowledge...hinder those who are entering - Jesus speaks about God's truth as if it were in a house that the teachers refuse to enter and will not let other enter either. This means the teachers do not truly know God, and they prevent others from knowing him as well.

metaphor.quote: trying to trap him in his own words
metaphor.notes: trying to trap him in his own words - This means they wanted Jesus to say something wrong so that they could accuse him.

metaphor.quote: Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy
metaphor.notes: Beware of the yeast of the Pharisees, which is hypocrisy - Just as yeast spreads through a whole lump of bread dough, their hypocrisy was spreading through the whole community. AT: "Guard yourself against the hypocrisy of the Pharisees, which is like yeast" or "Be careful that you do not become hypocrites like the Pharisees. Their evil behavior influences everyone just as yeast affects a lump of dough."

metaphor.quote: add a cubit to his lifespan
metaphor.notes: add a cubit to his lifespan - This is a metaphor because a cubit is a measure of length, rather than of time. The image is of a person's life stretched out as if it were a board, a rope, or some other physical object.

metaphor.quote: If God so clothes the grass in the field
metaphor.notes: If God so clothes the grass in the field - "If God clothes the grass in the field like that" or "If God gives the grass in the field such beautiful clothing." AT: "If God makes the grass in the field beautiful like this."

metaphor.quote: little flock
metaphor.notes: little flock - Jesus was calling his disciples a flock. A flock is a group of sheep or goats that a shepherd cares for. As a shepherd cares for his sheep, God would care for Jesus' disciples. AT: "small group" or "dear group."

metaphor.quote: Make for yourselves purses...treasure in the heavens
metaphor.notes: Make for yourselves purses...treasure in the heavens - The purses and treasure in the heavens are the same thing. They both represent God's blessing in heaven.

metaphor.quote: Make for yourselves purses...treasure in the heavens
metaphor.notes: Make for yourselves purses...treasure in the heavens - The purses and treasure in the heavens are the same thing. They both represent God's blessing in heaven.

metaphor.quote: I came to cast fire upon the earth
metaphor.notes: I came to cast fire upon the earth - "I came to throw fire on the earth" or "I came to set the earth on fire." Possible meanings are 1) Jesus has come to judge people or 2) Jesus has come to purify believers or 3) Jesus has come to cause division among people.

metaphor.quote: whom Satan bound
metaphor.notes: whom Satan bound - AT: "whom Satan kept crippled" or "whom Satan bound with this disease"

metaphor.quote: that fox
metaphor.notes: that fox - Jesus was calling Herod a fox. A fox is a small wild dog. Possible meanings are 1) Herod was not much of a threat at all 2) Herod was deceptive.

metaphor.quote: the way a hen gathers her brood under her wings
metaphor.notes: the way a hen gathers her brood under her wings - This describes how a hen protects her young from harm by covering them with her wings.

metaphor.quote: your house is abandoned
metaphor.notes: your house is abandoned - Possible meanings are 1) "God has abandoned you" or 2) "Your city is empty." It means that God has stopped protecting the people of Jerusalem, so enemies can attack them and drive them away. This is a prophecy about something that would happen soon. AT: "your house will be abandoned" or "God will abandon you."

metaphor.quote: carry his own cross
metaphor.notes: carry his own cross - The Romans often made a person carry his own cross before they crucified him. Jesus does not mean every Christian must be crucified. He means they must be willing to suffer in any way to be his disciple.

metaphor.quote: Salt is good
metaphor.notes: Salt is good - "Salt is useful." Jesus is teaching a lesson about those who want to be his disciple.

metaphor.quote: my son was dead, and now he is alive
metaphor.notes: my son was dead, and now he is alive - AT: "it is as if my son was dead and became alive again" or "I felt like my son had died, but he is alive"

metaphor.quote: He was lost, and now he is found
metaphor.notes: He was lost, and now he is found - AT: "It is as if my son was lost and now I found him" or "My son was lost and has returned home"

metaphor.quote: was dead, and is now alive
metaphor.notes: was dead, and is now alive - The son's leaving his family for a long period of time is compared to being dead, and his returning is compared to being alive again. It can be translated as a simile as it is in the UDB.

metaphor.quote: inherit
metaphor.notes: inherit - "become the rightful owner of." This usually refers to the property of someone who has died. Luke uses this metaphor to show that the ruler understood that eternal life could not be earned, and that not everyone will live eternally.

metaphor.quote: you will have treasure in heaven
metaphor.notes: you will have treasure in heaven - AT: "you will have God's blessings in heaven"

metaphor.quote: reap that which you did not sow
metaphor.notes: reap that which you did not sow - "reap what you did not plant." The servant was comparing his master to a farmer who takes food that someone else planted.

metaphor.quote: a den of robbers
metaphor.notes: a den of robbers - "a place where robbers hide out." AT: "like a den of robbers."

metaphor.quote: The stone which the builders rejected, has been made the cornerstone
metaphor.notes: The stone which the builders rejected, has been made the cornerstone - This metaphor is a prophecy from the book of Psalms about how people would reject the Messiah.

metaphor.quote: Every one that falls on that stone
metaphor.notes: Every one that falls on that stone - "Anyone who falls down onto that stone." This metaphor is a prophecy about what will happen to everyone who rejects the Messiah.

metaphor.quote: But on whomever it falls
metaphor.notes: But on whomever it falls - "But whomever that stone falls on." This metaphor is a prophecy about the Messiah judging those who reject him.

metaphor.quote: until I make your enemies your footstool
metaphor.notes: until I make your enemies your footstool - AT: "until I make your enemies like a footstool for you" or "until I conquer your enemies for you"

metaphor.quote: the youngest
metaphor.notes: the youngest - As leaders were most often older people and called "elders," "the youngest" would be the least likely to lead. AT: "the least important."

metaphor.quote: sift you as wheat
metaphor.notes: sift you as wheat - This means that Satan wanted to test the disciples to find something wrong. AT: "test you like someone shakes grain in a sieve"

metaphor.quote: remove this cup from me
metaphor.notes: remove this cup from me - Jesus is referring to the suffering that he is about to endure as if it were in a cup and that he was going to drink it. AT: "take away from me this cup of suffering" or "take away this suffering from me" or "rescue me from having to suffer like this."

metaphor.quote: the tree is green
metaphor.notes: the tree is green - The green tree is a metaphor for something good in the present. If your language has a similar metaphor, you should use it here.

metaphor.quote: it is dry
metaphor.notes: it is dry - The dry wood is a metaphor for something bad in the future.

metaphor.quote: the Sabbath was dawning
metaphor.notes: the Sabbath was dawning - "It was soon going to be sunset, the start of the Sabbath"

metaphor.quote: burning within us
metaphor.notes: burning within us - This is a metaphor that describes the intense feelings they had while talking to Jesus. AT: "We had such intense feelings while he was speaking to us."

doublet.notes: joy and gladness - These two words mean the same thing and could be combined if your language does not have similar terms. AT: "very glad."
silent, unable to speak - These mean the same thing, and are repeated to emphasize the completeness of his silence. AT: "completely unable to speak" or "not able to speak at all."
raised her voice...said loudly - These two phrases mean the same thing, and are used to emphasize how excited Elizabeth was. They could be combined into one phrase. AT: "exclaimed loudly."
raised her voice...said loudly - These two phrases mean the same thing, and are used to emphasize how excited Elizabeth was. They could be combined into one phrase. AT: "exclaimed loudly."

doublet.quote: My soul praises...my spirit has rejoiced
doublet.notes: My soul praises...my spirit has rejoiced - Mary is using a form of poetry where she states the same thing in two slightly different ways. If possible, translate these with two slightly different words or phrases that have that similar meaning.

doublet.quote: My soul praises...my spirit has rejoiced
doublet.notes: My soul praises...my spirit has rejoiced - Mary is using a form of poetry where she states the same thing in two slightly different ways. If possible, translate these with two slightly different words or phrases that have that similar meaning.
darkness...shadow of death - These two phrases work together to emphasize the deep spiritual darkness of people before God shows them mercy.
darkness...shadow of death - These two phrases work together to emphasize the deep spiritual darkness of people before God shows them mercy.
glorifying and praising God - These are very similar and emphasize how excited they were about what God had done. AT: "talking about and praising God's greatness."

doublet.quote: if you will bow down before me...worship me
doublet.notes: if you will bow down before me...worship me - These two phrases are very similar. They could be combined. AT: "if you will bow down in worship to me."

doublet.quote: if you will bow down before me...worship me
doublet.notes: if you will bow down before me...worship me - These two phrases are very similar. They could be combined. AT: "if you will bow down in worship to me."
crying out and saying - These mean about the same thing, and probably refer to cries of fear or anger. Some translations use only one term. AT: "screaming" or "shouting."
love...do good to - These two phrases mean the same thing, and together emphasize the point.
love...do good to - These two phrases mean the same thing, and together emphasize the point.

activepassive.quote: he will be filled with the Holy Spirit
activepassive.notes: he will be filled with the Holy Spirit - This could be stated as an active phrase: AT: "the Holy Spirit will empower him" or "the Holy Spirit will guide him." Make sure it does not sound similar to what an evil spirit might do to a person.

activepassive.quote: I was sent to speak to you
activepassive.notes: I was sent to speak to you - This can be stated in active form. AT: "God sent me to speak to you."

activepassive.quote: the angel Gabriel was sent from God
activepassive.notes: the angel Gabriel was sent from God - This can be stated in active form: AT: "God told the angel Gabriel to go"

activepassive.quote: will be called
activepassive.notes: will be called - Possible meanings are 1) "people will call him" or 2) "God will call him."

activepassive.quote: will be called
activepassive.notes: will be called - Possible meanings are 1) "people will call him" or 2) "God will call him."

activepassive.quote: the things that were told her from the Lord
activepassive.notes: the things that were told her from the Lord - AT: "the message that the Lord gave to her" or "the things that the Lord told you"

activepassive.quote: his mouth was opened and his tongue was freed
activepassive.notes: his mouth was opened and his tongue was freed - These phrases can also be stated in active form. AT: "God opened his mouth and freed his tongue."

activepassive.quote: His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit
activepassive.notes: His father Zechariah was filled with the Holy Spirit - This could be stated in active form. AT: "The Holy Spirit filled his father Zechariah."

activepassive.quote: you, child, will be called a prophet
activepassive.notes: you, child, will be called a prophet - People will realize that he is a prophet. This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will know that you are a prophet."

activepassive.quote: by the forgiveness of their sins
activepassive.notes: by the forgiveness of their sins - "through the forgiveness of their sins." The could also be stated in active form. AT: because God has forgiven them."

activepassive.quote: that a census be taken of all the people living in the Roman world
activepassive.notes: that a census be taken of all the people living in the Roman world - This can be stated in active form. AT: "that they register all the people living in the Roman world" or "that they count all the people in the Roman world and write down their names."

activepassive.quote: This is the sign that will be given to you
activepassive.notes: This is the sign that will be given to you - This could be stated in active form. AT: "God will give you this sign" or "You will see this sign from God."

activepassive.quote: what had been said to them
activepassive.notes: what had been said to them - This can be stated in active form. AT: "what the angels had told the shepherds."

activepassive.quote: what was spoken to them by the shepherds
activepassive.notes: what was spoken to them by the shepherds - This can be stated in active form. AT: "what the shepherds told them."

activepassive.quote: the name he had been given by the angel
activepassive.notes: the name he had been given by the angel - This can be stated in active form. AT: "the name the angel had called him."

activepassive.quote: the required number of days
activepassive.notes: the required number of days - This could be stated in active form. AT: "the number of days that God required."

activepassive.quote: As it is written
activepassive.notes: As it is written - This could be stated in active form. AT: "As Moses wrote" or "They did this because Moses wrote."

activepassive.quote: will be called dedicated
activepassive.notes: will be called dedicated - This could be stated in active form. AT: "you must dedicate" or "you must set apart."

activepassive.quote: It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit
activepassive.notes: It had been revealed to him by the Holy Spirit - This can be stated in active form. AT: "The Holy Spirit had shown him" or "The Holy Spirit had told him."

activepassive.quote: led by the Holy Spirit
activepassive.notes: led by the Holy Spirit - This could be stated in active form. AT: "as the Holy Spirit directed him."

activepassive.quote: the things which were spoken concerning him
activepassive.notes: the things which were spoken concerning him - This can be stated in active form. AT: "the things that Simeon said about him."

activepassive.quote: This child is destined for the falling and rising of many people in Israel
activepassive.notes: This child is destined for the falling and rising of many people in Israel - The words "rising" and "falling" express turning away from God and drawing closer to God. AT: "God has caused many people in Israel to fall away from God or to rise closer to God."

activepassive.quote: they were required to do according to the law of the Lord
activepassive.notes: they were required to do according to the law of the Lord - This could be stated in active form. AT: "that the law of the Lord required them to do."

activepassive.quote: As it is written...prophet
activepassive.notes: As it is written...prophet - Verses 4-6 are a quotation from Isaiah. They could be stated in active form. AT: "This happened as Isaiah the prophet had written in his book" or "John fulfilled the words that the prophet Isaiah had written in his book."

activepassive.quote: As it is written...prophet
activepassive.notes: As it is written...prophet - Verses 4-6 are a quotation from Isaiah. They could be stated in active form. AT: "This happened as Isaiah the prophet had written in his book" or "John fulfilled the words that the prophet Isaiah had written in his book."

activepassive.quote: Every valley will be filled
activepassive.notes: Every valley will be filled - This could be stated in active form. AT: "They will fill in every low place in the road."

activepassive.quote: every mountain and hill will be made level
activepassive.notes: every mountain and hill will be made level - This could be stated in active form. AT: "they will level every mountain and hill" or "they will remove every high place in the the road"

activepassive.quote: to be baptized by him
activepassive.notes: to be baptized by him - This can be stated in active form. AT: "for John to baptize them"

activepassive.quote: from the wrath that is coming
activepassive.notes: from the wrath that is coming - The word "wrath" is used here to refer to God's punishment because his wrath precedes it. AT: "from the punishment that God is sending" or "from God's wrath on which he is about to act"

activepassive.quote: to be baptized
activepassive.notes: to be baptized - This could be stated in active form. AT: "for John to baptize them."

activepassive.quote: than you are supposed to
activepassive.notes: than you are supposed to - This clause is passive to show that the tax collector's authority comes from Rome. AT: "than what the Romans have authorized you to take."

activepassive.quote: while all the people were being baptized by John
activepassive.notes: while all the people were being baptized by John - "while John was baptizing all the people." The phrase "all the people" refers to the people present with John.

activepassive.quote: Jesus also was baptized
activepassive.notes: Jesus also was baptized - AT: "John baptized Jesus, too"

activepassive.quote: was led by the Spirit
activepassive.notes: was led by the Spirit - This could be stated in active form. AT: "the Spirit led him."

activepassive.quote: was tempted there by the devil
activepassive.notes: was tempted there by the devil - This could be stated in active form. AT: "the devil tempted him there to disobey God."

activepassive.quote: It is written
activepassive.notes: It is written - The quotation is from Moses' writings in the Old Testament. This could be stated in active form. AT: "Moses has written in the scriptures."

activepassive.quote: they have been given to me to rule over
activepassive.notes: they have been given to me to rule over - Since God is the only one who could give this authority to the devil, this could be stated in active form. AT: "God has permitted me to control them all"

activepassive.quote: It is written
activepassive.notes: It is written - This could be stated in active form. AT: "Moses has written in the scriptures."

activepassive.quote: it is written
activepassive.notes: it is written - This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Psalmist has written."

activepassive.quote: It is said
activepassive.notes: It is said - Jesus quotes from the writings of Moses in Deuteronomy. This can be stated in active form. AT: "Moses has said" or "Moses has said in the scriptures."

activepassive.quote: news about him spread
activepassive.notes: news about him spread - Those who heard Jesus told other people about him, and then those other people told even more people about him. This could be stated in active form. AT: "people spread the news about Jesus" or "people told other people about Jesus" or "knowledge about him was passed on from person to person."

activepassive.quote: The scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him
activepassive.notes: The scroll of the prophet Isaiah was handed to him - This can be stated in active form. AT: "Someone gave him the scroll of the prophet Isaiah."

activepassive.quote: this scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing
activepassive.notes: this scripture has been fulfilled in your hearing - Jesus was saying that he was fulfilling that prophecy by his actions and speech at that very time. This could be stated in active form. AT: "I am fulfilling what this scripture said right now as you are listening to me."

activepassive.quote: this is the reason I was sent here
activepassive.notes: this is the reason I was sent here - This could be stated in active form. AT: "this is the reason God sent me here."

activepassive.quote: the report about him spread even farther
activepassive.notes: the report about him spread even farther - "the report about him went out even farther." This could be stated in active form. AT: "people kept telling the news about him in other places."

activepassive.quote: your sins are forgiven you
activepassive.notes: your sins are forgiven you - This could be stated in active form. AT: "you are forgiven" or "I forgive your sins"

activepassive.quote: the wine would be spilled
activepassive.notes: the wine would be spilled - This could be stated in active form. AT: "the wine would spill out of the bags"

activepassive.quote: to be healed
activepassive.notes: to be healed - This could be stated in active form. AT: "for Jesus to heal them."

activepassive.quote: People who were troubled with unclean spirits were also healed
activepassive.notes: People who were troubled with unclean spirits were also healed - This could be stated in active form. AT: "Jesus also healed people who were troubled with unclean spirits."

activepassive.quote: power to heal was coming out from him
activepassive.notes: power to heal was coming out from him - This could be stated in active form. AT: "he had power to heal people" or "he used his power to heal people."

activepassive.quote: you will not be judged
activepassive.notes: you will not be judged - Jesus did not say who would not judge. Possible meanings are 1) "God will not judge you" or 2) "no one will judge you."

activepassive.quote: you will not be condemned
activepassive.notes: you will not be condemned - Jesus did not say who would not condemn. Possible meanings are 1) "God will not condemn you" or 2) "no one will condemn you."

activepassive.quote: you will be forgiven
activepassive.notes: you will be forgiven - Jesus did not say who would forgive. Possible meanings are 1) "God will forgive you" or 2) "people will forgive you."

activepassive.quote: it will be given to you
activepassive.notes: it will be given to you - Jesus did not say exactly who would give. Possible meanings are 1) "someone will give it to you" or 2) "God will give it to you."

activepassive.quote: that same standard will be used to measure for you
activepassive.notes: that same standard will be used to measure for you - Jesus did not say exactly who would measure. Possible meanings are 1) "they will measure things for you by that same standard" or 2) "God will use that same standard to measure for you."

activepassive.quote: each tree is known
activepassive.notes: each tree is known - People recognize the kind of tree by the fruit is bears. This could be stated in active form. AT: "people know the type of a tree" or "people recognize a tree."

activepassive.quote: because it had been well built
activepassive.notes: because it had been well built - "because the man had built it well"

activepassive.quote: I also am a man who is placed under authority
activepassive.notes: I also am a man who is placed under authority - This can the stated in active form. AT: "I also have a person over me that I must obey."

activepassive.quote: a dead man was being carried out
activepassive.notes: a dead man was being carried out - This could be stated in active form. AT: "people carried a dead man out."

activepassive.quote: fear overcame all of them
activepassive.notes: fear overcame all of them - "fear filled all of them." This could be stated in active form. AT: "they all became very afraid."

activepassive.quote: has been raised among us
activepassive.notes: has been raised among us - "has come to be with us" or "has appeared to us." This could be stated in active form. AT: "God has raised a great prophet among us."

activepassive.quote: The person who does not stop believing in me because of my actions is blessed
activepassive.notes: The person who does not stop believing in me because of my actions is blessed - This could be stated in active form. AT: "God will bless the person who does not stop believing in me because of my actions."

activepassive.quote: who had been baptized with the baptism of John
activepassive.notes: who had been baptized with the baptism of John - "who had been baptized by John" or "whom John had baptized"

activepassive.quote: who were not baptized by him, rejected God's wisdom for themselves
activepassive.notes: who were not baptized by him, rejected God's wisdom for themselves - This seems to imply that because they had rejected John's baptism, they were not spiritually prepared to accept God's will for them.

activepassive.quote: has been forgiven much
activepassive.notes: has been forgiven much - AT: "who has received much forgiveness" or "whom God has forgiven much"

activepassive.quote: Your sins are forgiven
activepassive.notes: Your sins are forgiven - "You are forgiven." AT: "I forgive your sins."

activepassive.quote: who had been healed of evil spirits and diseases
activepassive.notes: who had been healed of evil spirits and diseases - "whom Jesus had set free from evil spirits and healed of diseases"

activepassive.quote: they were trampled underfoot
activepassive.notes: they were trampled underfoot - AT: "They were stepped on too often for them to grow" or use an active verb as in the UDB.

activepassive.quote: so that they may not believe and be saved
activepassive.notes: so that they may not believe and be saved - Since this is the devil's purpose, it can be translated as AT: "because the devil thinks, 'They must not believe and they must not be saved'" or "so they may not believe with the result that God saves them."

activepassive.quote: to him will be given more
activepassive.notes: to him will be given more - "more will be given to him." AT: "God will give him more"

activepassive.quote: it was told him
activepassive.notes: it was told him - AT: "people told him" or "someone told him"

activepassive.quote: Even though he was bound...and kept under guard
activepassive.notes: Even though he was bound...and kept under guard - "Even though the people had bound him...and shackles and guarded him"

activepassive.quote: Even though he was bound...and kept under guard
activepassive.notes: Even though he was bound...and kept under guard - "Even though the people had bound him...and shackles and guarded him"

activepassive.quote: the man who was controlled by demons had been saved
activepassive.notes: the man who was controlled by demons had been saved - AT: "Jesus had saved the man that demons had controlled" or Jesus had healed the man that demons had controlled"

activepassive.quote: they were gripped with great fear
activepassive.notes: they were gripped with great fear - "they became very fearful." or AT: "great fear filled them."

activepassive.quote: but could not be healed by any of them
activepassive.notes: but could not be healed by any of them - AT: "but none of them could cure her" or "but none of them could heal her"

activepassive.quote: she will be saved
activepassive.notes: she will be saved - AT: "I will heal her"

activepassive.quote: the ones who had been sent out
activepassive.notes: the ones who had been sent out - AT: "the twelve apostles that Jesus had sent out"

activepassive.quote: and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes
activepassive.notes: and be rejected by the elders and chief priests and scribes - AT: "and the elders, chief priests, and scribes will reject him"

activepassive.quote: and he will be killed
activepassive.notes: and he will be killed - AT: "and the people will kill him"

activepassive.quote: be raised back to life
activepassive.notes: be raised back to life - "be made alive again." AT: "God will make him alive again" or "he will come back to life"

activepassive.quote: as they were surrounded by the cloud
activepassive.notes: as they were surrounded by the cloud - AT: "as the cloud surrounded them"

activepassive.quote: for the Son of Man will be delivered over into the hands of men
activepassive.notes: for the Son of Man will be delivered over into the hands of men - Here "hands" refer to power or control. AT: "Men will hand the Son of Man over to the authorities."

activepassive.quote: and it was concealed from them
activepassive.notes: and it was concealed from them - AT: "God hid the meaning from them"
