activepassive.notes: eat what is set before you - AT: "eat whatever food they give you"

activepassive.notes: If the mighty works which were done in you had been done in Tyre and Sidon - Jesus is describing a situation that could have happened in the past but did not. AT: "If someone had performed the miracles for the people of Tyre and Sidon that I performed for you"

activepassive.notes: do you think you will be exalted to heaven - Jesus uses a question to rebuke the people of Capernaum for their pride. AT: "you will certainly not go up to heaven" or "God will not honor you."

activepassive.notes: you will be brought down to hades - AT: "you will go down to hades" or "God will send you to hades"

activepassive.notes: All things have been entrusted to me from my Father - AT: "My Father has handed everything over to me"

activepassive.notes: What is written in the law? - Jesus uses a question to teach the Jewish teacher. AT: "Tell me what Moses wrote in the law."

activepassive.quote: which will not be taken away from her
activepassive.notes: which will not be taken away from her - Possible meanings are 1) "I will not take this opportunity away from her" or 2) "She will not lose what she has gained as she listening to me."

activepassive.quote: it will be given to you
activepassive.notes: it will be given to you - AT: "God will give it to you" or "you will receive it"

activepassive.quote: it will be opened to you
activepassive.notes: it will be opened to you - AT: "God will open the door for you" or "God will welcome you inside"

activepassive.notes: Every kingdom divided against itself is made desolate - AT: "If people of a kingdom fight among themselves, they will destroy their kingdom"

activepassive.notes: no sign will be given to it - AT: "God will not give them a sign"

activepassive.notes: the whole body is filled with light - Jesus speaks about truth as if it were light. AT: "the light of truth will fill your whole life" or "your whole life is full of truth."

activepassive.notes: This generation, then, will be held responsible for all the blood of the prophets shed - The blood that was shed refers to the murder of the prophets. AT: "Therefore, God will hold this generation responsible for all the deaths of the prophets that people have killed"

activepassive.quote: who was killed
activepassive.notes: who was killed - AT: "that the people killed"

activepassive.notes: But there is nothing concealed, that will not be revealed - "But everything that is hidden will be shown." The word "but" is a connecting word. AT: "But people will find out about everything that people do secretly."

activepassive.notes: and nothing hidden, that will not be known - This means the same thing as the first part of the sentence in order to emphasize its truth. AT: "and people will learn about what others try to hide."

activepassive.quote: will be heard in the light
activepassive.notes: will be heard in the light - AT: "people will hear in the light"

activepassive.quote: will be proclaimed
activepassive.notes: will be proclaimed - "will be shouted loudly." AT: "people will proclaim"

activepassive.quote: will be denied
activepassive.notes: will be denied - "will be disowned." AT: "The Son of Man will deny him " or "I will deny that he is my disciple."

activepassive.notes: it will be forgiven him - "he will be forgiven." AT: "God will forgive him for that."

activepassive.notes: tonight your soul is required of you - AT: "you will die tonight" or "I will take your life from you tonight"

activepassive.notes: these things will be added to you - "these things also will be given to you." "These things" refers to food and clothing. AT: "God will give you these things."

activepassive.notes: Let your long clothing be tucked in at your belt - People wore long flowing robes. They would tuck them into their belt to keep the robes out of the way while they worked. AT: "Tuck your clothing into your belt so you are ready to serve" or "Be dressed and ready to serve."

activepassive.notes: will be beaten with many blows - "will be hit many times" or "will be whipped many times." AT: "his master will hit him many times" or "his master will punish him severely."

activepassive.notes: Everyone to whom much is given, much will be required of him - AT: "They will require more of anyone who has received much" or "The master will require more of everyone he has given much to"

activepassive.notes: to whom they entrust much - AT: "to whom they give much property to take care of" or "to whom they give much responsibility"

activepassive.notes: they entrust...they will ask - The word "they" here does not refer to a specific group of people. AT: "the master entrusts...the master will ask." If you translated the previous sentences with a passive verb, consider following the UDB.

activepassive.quote: they entrust...they will ask
activepassive.notes: they entrust...they will ask - The word "they" here does not refer to a specific group of people. AT: "the master entrusts...the master will ask." If you translated the previous sentences with a passive verb, consider following the UDB.

activepassive.notes: But I have a baptism to be baptized with - Here "baptism" refers to what Jesus must suffer. Just as water covers a person during baptism, suffering will overwhelm Jesus. AT: "I must go through a baptism of terrible suffering"

activepassive.notes: she was straightened up - AT: "she stood up straight"

activepassive.quote: Come and be healed then
activepassive.notes: Come and be healed then - AT: "Come and let someone heal you during those six days"

activepassive.quote: should her bonds not be untied...day?
activepassive.notes: should her bonds not be untied...day? - Jesus uses a question to teach the synagogue rulers. Jesus speaks about the women's disease as if it were ropes that bound her. AT: "it is right to untie her from Satan...day" or "it is right to release her from the bonds of this illness...day."

activepassive.quote: should her bonds not be untied...day?
activepassive.notes: should her bonds not be untied...day? - Jesus uses a question to teach the synagogue rulers. Jesus speaks about the women's disease as if it were ropes that bound her. AT: "it is right to untie her from Satan...day" or "it is right to release her from the bonds of this illness...day."

activepassive.quote: are only a few people to be saved
activepassive.notes: are only a few people to be saved - AT: "will God save only a few people"

activepassive.quote: but youâ€”you were thrown outside
activepassive.notes: but youâ€”you were thrown outside - "but you yourselves will have been thrown outside." AT: "but God will have forced you outside."

activepassive.quote: who kills the prophets and stones those sent to you
activepassive.notes: who kills the prophets and stones those sent to you - If it would be strange to address the city, you can make it clear that Jesus was really addressing the people in the city: "you people who kill the prophets and stone those God has sent to you"

activepassive.quote: those who were invited
activepassive.notes: those who were invited - AT: "those whom the leader of the Pharisees had invited to the meal"

activepassive.notes: When you are invited by someone - AT: "When someone invites you"

activepassive.notes: when you are invited - AT: "when someone invites you to a meal"

activepassive.quote: Then you will be honored
activepassive.notes: Then you will be honored - AT: "Then the one who invited you will honor you"

activepassive.quote: will be humbled
activepassive.notes: will be humbled - "will be shown to be unimportant" or "will be given an unimportant position." AT: "God will humble."

activepassive.quote: will be exalted
activepassive.notes: will be exalted - "will be shown to be important" or "will be given an important position." AT: "God will exalt."

activepassive.quote: and you will be repaid
activepassive.notes: and you will be repaid - AT: "and in this way repay you"

activepassive.quote: you will be blessed
activepassive.notes: you will be blessed - AT: "God will bless you"

activepassive.quote: you will be repaid in the resurrection of the just
activepassive.notes: you will be repaid in the resurrection of the just - AT: "God will repay you when he brings the righteous people back to life"

activepassive.quote: those who were invited
activepassive.notes: those who were invited - AT: "those he had invited"

activepassive.quote: what you commanded has been done
activepassive.notes: what you commanded has been done - AT: "I have done what you commanded"

activepassive.quote: who were first invited
activepassive.notes: who were first invited - AT: "whom I first invited"

activepassive.quote: how can it be made salty again?
activepassive.notes: how can it be made salty again? - Jesus uses a question to teach the crowd. AT: "It cannot be made salty again" or "No one can make it salty again."

activepassive.quote: It is thrown away

activepassive.notes: I am not worthy to be called your son - AT: "I am not worthy for you to call me son"

activepassive.notes: he was lost, and has now been found - The younger brother's being away from his family for a long period of time is compared to being lost, and his return home is compared to being found. activepassive.notes: A certain beggar named Lazarus was laid at his gate - AT: "people had laid a certain beggar named Lazarus at his gate"

activepassive.notes: was carried away by the angels - AT: "the angels carried him away"

activepassive.notes: and was buried - AT: "and people buried him"

activepassive.notes: he is comforted here - AT: "he is comfortable here" or "he is happy here"

activepassive.notes: a great chasm has been firmly placed - AT: "God has placed a huge ravine between you and us"

activepassive.notes: if a millstone were put around his neck and he were thrown - AT: "if they were to put a millstone around his neck and throw him" or "if someone were to put a heavy stone around his neck and push him"

activepassive.notes: Be uprooted, and be planted in the sea - AT: "Uproot yourself and plant yourself in the sea" or "Take your roots out of the ground, and put your roots down into the ocean"

activepassive.quote: the things that were commanded
activepassive.notes: the things that were commanded - AT: "the things you commanded him to do"

activepassive.quote: that you are commanded
activepassive.notes: that you are commanded - AT: "that God has commanded you"

activepassive.quote: there he was met by ten men who were lepers
activepassive.notes: there he was met by ten men who were lepers - AT: "ten men who were lepers met him" or "ten men who had leprosy met him"

activepassive.quote: Were not the ten cleansed?
activepassive.notes: Were not the ten cleansed? - This is the first of three rhetorical questions. Jesus used them to show the people around him how surprised and disappointed he was that only one of the ten men came back to glorify God. AT: "Ten men were healed" or "God healed ten men."

activepassive.quote: The kingdom of God is not something that can be observed
activepassive.notes: The kingdom of God is not something that can be observed - They would not see that Jesus was already among them as the king because they were looking for a physical kingdom. AT: "Although you look for the kingdom of God, you will not see it."

activepassive.quote: and be rejected by this generation
activepassive.notes: and be rejected by this generation - AT: "and this generation must reject him"

activepassive.quote: they were given in marriage
activepassive.notes: they were given in marriage - AT: "parents were allowing their daughters to marry men"

activepassive.quote: in the day that the Son of Man is revealed
activepassive.notes: in the day that the Son of Man is revealed - AT: "when the Son of Man appears" or "when the Son of man comes"

activepassive.quote: One will be taken, and the other will be left
activepassive.notes: One will be taken, and the other will be left - "One person will be taken and the other person will be left behind." AT: "God will take one person and leave the other" or "angels will take one and leave behind the other."

activepassive.quote: will be humbled
activepassive.notes: will be humbled - AT: "God will humble"

activepassive.quote: will be exalted
activepassive.notes: will be exalted - AT: "God will greatly honor"

activepassive.quote: Then who can be saved?
activepassive.notes: Then who can be saved? - It is possible that they were asking for an answer. But it is more likely that they used the question to emphasize their surprise at what Jesus said. AT: "Then no one can be saved from sin!" or "Then God will not save anyone!"

activepassive.quote: that have been written by the prophets
activepassive.notes: that have been written by the prophets - AT: "that the prophets have written"

activepassive.quote: will be accomplished
activepassive.notes: will be accomplished - AT: "will happen" or "will occur"

activepassive.quote: For he will be given over to the Gentiles
activepassive.notes: For he will be given over to the Gentiles - AT: "For the Jewish leaders will give him over to the Gentiles"

activepassive.quote: and will be mocked, and shamefully treated, and spit upon
activepassive.notes: and will be mocked, and shamefully treated, and spit upon - AT: "and they will mock him, treat him shamefully, and spit on him"

activepassive.quote: this word was hidden from them
activepassive.notes: this word was hidden from them - AT: "God prevented them from understanding the meaning of what he was telling them"

activepassive.quote: the things that were said
activepassive.notes: the things that were said - AT: "the things that Jesus said"

activepassive.quote: that the man be brought to him
activepassive.notes: that the man be brought to him - AT: "the people to bring the blind man to him"

activepassive.quote: to be called to him
activepassive.notes: to be called to him - AT: "to come to him"

activepassive.quote: will be given more
activepassive.notes: will be given more - AT: "I will give him more"

activepassive.quote: will be taken away
activepassive.notes: will be taken away - AT: "I will take away from him"

activepassive.quote: that has never been ridden
activepassive.notes: that has never been ridden - AT: "that no one has ever ridden"

activepassive.quote: Those who were sent
activepassive.notes: Those who were sent - AT: "Those Jesus had sent" or "The two disciples that Jesus sent"

activepassive.quote: they are hidden from your eyes
activepassive.notes: they are hidden from your eyes - AT: "you can no longer see them" or "you are unable to know it"

activepassive.quote: It is written
activepassive.notes: It is written - This is a quotation from Isaiah. AT: "The scriptures say" or "A prophet wrote these words in the scriptures."

activepassive.quote: has been made the cornerstone
activepassive.notes: has been made the cornerstone - This was an important stone for making a building stable. AT: "has become the chief stone" or "has become the most important stone."

activepassive.quote: will be broken to pieces
activepassive.notes: will be broken to pieces - "will break up into pieces." This is a result of falling onto the stone.

activepassive.quote: are not influenced by anyone
activepassive.notes: are not influenced by anyone - Possible meanings are 1) "you tell the truth even if important people do not like it"

activepassive.quote: marry, and are given in marriage
activepassive.notes: marry, and are given in marriage - In that culture they spoke of men marrying women and women being given in marriage to their husband. AT: "get married."

activepassive.quote: they who are judged to be worthy
activepassive.notes: they who are judged to be worthy - AT: "the people whom God has considered to be worthy"

activepassive.quote: But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed
activepassive.notes: But that the dead are raised, even Moses showed - The word "even" is here because the Sadducees might not have been surprised that some scriptures say that the dead are raised, but they did not expect Moses to have written something like that. AT: "But even Moses showed that dead people rise from the dead."

activepassive.quote: not one stone will be left on another
activepassive.notes: not one stone will be left on another - "every stone will be removed from its place." AT: "enemies will not leave any stone on top of another."

activepassive.quote: which will not be torn down
activepassive.notes: which will not be torn down - This can be translated as a new sentence. AT: "They will all be torn down" or "Enemies will tear down every stone."

activepassive.quote: that you are not deceived
activepassive.notes: that you are not deceived - Jesus was talking to his disciples. The word "you" is plural. AT: "that you do not believe lies" or "that no one deceives you."

activepassive.quote: you will be delivered up also by parents, brothers, relatives and friends
activepassive.notes: you will be delivered up also by parents, brothers, relatives and friends - AT: "your parents, brothers, relatives, and friends will hand you over to the authorities"

activepassive.quote: Jerusalem surrounded by armies
activepassive.notes: Jerusalem surrounded by armies - AT: "armies surrounding Jerusalem"

activepassive.quote: all the things that are written
activepassive.notes: all the things that are written - AT: "all the things that the prophets wrote in the scriptures long ago"

activepassive.quote: will be fulfilled
activepassive.notes: will be fulfilled - AT: "will happen"

activepassive.quote: they will be led captive into all the nations
activepassive.notes: they will be led captive into all the nations - AT: "their enemies will capture them and take them to other countries"

activepassive.quote: Jerusalem will be trampled by the Gentiles
activepassive.notes: Jerusalem will be trampled by the Gentiles - Possible meanings are 1) the Gentiles will conquer Jerusalem and occupy it or 2) the Gentiles will destroy the city of Jerusalem or 3) the Gentiles will destroy the people of Jerusalem.

activepassive.quote: the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled
activepassive.notes: the times of the Gentiles are fulfilled - AT: "the period of the Gentiles has come to an end"

activepassive.quote: the powers of the heavens will be shaken
activepassive.notes: the powers of the heavens will be shaken - Possible meanings are 1) the things in the sky like the sun, moon, and stars will not move in their normal way or 2) the powerful spirits in the heavens will be distressed. The first is recommended. AT: "God will shake the powerful things in the heavens."

activepassive.quote: the Passover lamb must be sacrificed
activepassive.notes: the Passover lamb must be sacrificed - Each family or group of people would kill a lamb and eat it together, so many lambs were killed. AT: "people had to kill the lamb for the Passover meal."

activepassive.quote: until it is fulfilled
activepassive.notes: until it is fulfilled - Possible meanings are 1) "until the purpose of the Passover Festival is accomplished" or 2) "until we eat celebrate the final Passover Festival." AT: "until God fulfills it" or "until God completes the purpose of the Passover Festival."

activepassive.quote: my body which is given for you
activepassive.notes: my body which is given for you - "my body, which I will give for you" or "my body, which I will sacrifice for you." AT: "my body, that I give to the authorities to kill for your sake."

activepassive.quote: as it has been determined
activepassive.notes: as it has been determined - AT: "as God has determined" or "as God has planned"

activepassive.quote: But woe to that man through whom he is betrayed!
activepassive.notes: But woe to that man through whom he is betrayed! - AT: "But woe to the man who betrays the Son of Man!" or "But how terrible it will be for that man who betrays the Son of Man!"

activepassive.quote: was considered to be greatest
activepassive.notes: was considered to be greatest - AT: "the people would think is most important"

activepassive.quote: what is written about me
activepassive.notes: what is written about me - AT: "what a prophet wrote about me in the scriptures"

activepassive.quote: must be fulfilled
activepassive.notes: must be fulfilled - The apostles would have understood that God would cause everything written in the scriptures to happen. AT: "God will fulfill" or "God will cause to happen."

activepassive.quote: he was regarded as one of the lawless
activepassive.notes: he was regarded as one of the lawless - Here Jesus is quoting the scriptures. AT: "people considered him to be one of the lawless people."

activepassive.quote: For what is predicted about me is being fulfilled
activepassive.notes: For what is predicted about me is being fulfilled - Possible meanings are 1) "For what the prophet predicted about me is about to happen" or 2) "For my life is coming to an end."

activepassive.quote: Nevertheless not my will, but yours be done
activepassive.notes: Nevertheless not my will, but yours be done - AT: "However, I want to do what is according to your will rather than what is according to my will"

activepassive.quote: They led him into the Council
activepassive.notes: They led him into the Council - Possible meanings are 1) "The elders had Jesus brought into the Council" or 2) "The guards led Jesus into the Council of the elders." Some languages may avoid saying who led him by using the pronoun "they"

activepassive.quote: to see some miracle done by him
activepassive.notes: to see some miracle done by him - AT: "to see him perform some kind of miracle"

activepassive.quote: nothing worthy of death has been done by him
activepassive.notes: nothing worthy of death has been done by him - AT: "he has not done anything to deserve a death sentence"

activepassive.quote: who had been put into prison
activepassive.notes: who had been put into prison - AT: "whom the Romans had put in prison"

activepassive.quote: for him to be crucified
activepassive.notes: for him to be crucified - AT: "for Pilate to have his soldiers crucify Jesus"

activepassive.quote: who had been put in prison
activepassive.notes: who had been put in prison - AT: "whom the Romans had put in prison"

activepassive.quote: Other men, two criminals, were led away with him to be put to death
activepassive.notes: Other men, two criminals, were led away with him to be put to death - AT: "The soldiers led away with Jesus two criminals to execute them also"

activepassive.quote: who was crucified
activepassive.notes: who was crucified - AT: "who was also hanging on a cross"

activepassive.quote: was split down the middle
activepassive.notes: was split down the middle - "was torn into two pieces." AT: "God tore the temple curtain into two pieces."

activepassive.quote: what was done
activepassive.notes: what was done - AT: "what had happened"

activepassive.quote: things that were done
activepassive.notes: things that were done - AT: "what had happened"

activepassive.quote: that was cut in stone
activepassive.notes: that was cut in stone - AT: "a tomb which someone had cut in a rock cliff"

activepassive.quote: how his body was laid
activepassive.notes: how his body was laid - AT: "the women saw how the men laid Jesus' body inside the tomb"

activepassive.quote: the stone rolled away
activepassive.notes: the stone rolled away - AT: "that someone had rolled the stone"

activepassive.quote: the Son of Man must be delivered up into the hands of sinful men and be crucified
activepassive.notes: the Son of Man must be delivered up into the hands of sinful men and be crucified - This is something that would certainly happen because God had already decided that it would happen. AT: "it was necessary that they hand the Son of Man over to sinful men so they can crucify him."

activepassive.quote: their eyes were prevented from recognizing him
activepassive.notes: their eyes were prevented from recognizing him - "their eyes were kept from recognizing Jesus." The men's ability to recognize Jesus is spoken of as their eyes' ability to recognize him. AT: "they were kept from recognizing him" or "something prevented them so they could not recognize him."

activepassive.quote: delivered him up to be condemned to death and crucified him
activepassive.notes: delivered him up to be condemned to death and crucified him - AT: "handed Jesus over to the Roman governor in order for the governor to put Jesus to death by crucifying him"

activepassive.quote: Then their eyes were opened
activepassive.notes: Then their eyes were opened - AT: "then they understood" or "then they realized"

activepassive.quote: how Jesus was shown to them
activepassive.notes: how Jesus was shown to them - AT: "how they recognized Jesus"

activepassive.quote: all that was written in the law of Moses and the prophets and the Psalms
activepassive.notes: all that was written in the law of Moses and the prophets and the Psalms - AT: "all that Moses, the prophets, and the writers of the Psalms wrote about me"

activepassive.quote: must be fulfilled
activepassive.notes: must be fulfilled - AT: "God would fulfill" or "God would cause to happen"

activepassive.quote: Thus it is written
activepassive.notes: Thus it is written - AT: "This is what people long ago wrote"

activepassive.quote: repentance and forgiveness of sins should be preached
activepassive.notes: repentance and forgiveness of sins should be preached - AT: "the Messiah's followers should preach that people need to repent and have God forgive their sins"

activepassive.quote: you are clothed with power
activepassive.notes: you are clothed with power - God's power will cover them in the same way that clothes cover a person. AT: "you receive power."

activepassive.quote: was carried
activepassive.notes: was carried - Since Luke does not specify who carried Jesus up, we don't know if it was God himself or one or more angels. If your language has to specify who did the carrying, it would be best to go with the UDB "went."

metonymy.quote: give him the throne of his ancestor David
metonymy.notes: give him the throne of his ancestor David - The throne represents the king's authority to rule. AT: "give him authority to rule as king as his ancestor David did."
his name - Here "name" refers to the entire person of God. AT: "he."
displayed strength with his arm - "his arm" is a metonymy that refers to his God's power. AT: "shown that he is very powerful."

metonymy.quote: the hand of the Lord was with him
metonymy.notes: the hand of the Lord was with him - The phrase "the hand of the Lord" refers to the Lord's power. "The Lord's power was with him" or "The Lord was working in him powerfully."
hand - "power" or "control." The word "hand" is associated with the power or control that is being used to harm God's people.

metonymy.quote: out of the hand of our enemies
metonymy.notes: out of the hand of our enemies - "hand" refers to the control or power a person. This could be stated clearly. AT: "from the control of our enemies."
your salvation - This expression refers to the person who would bring salvationâ€”the infant Jesusâ€”whom Simeon was holding. AT: "the savior whom you sent" or "the one whom you sent to save"

metonymy.quote: the thoughts from many hearts may be revealed
metonymy.notes: the thoughts from many hearts may be revealed - AT: "the thoughts of many people will be revealed."

the redemption of Jerusalem - Here the word "redemption" is used to refer to the the person who would do it. AT: "the one who would redeem Jerusalem" or "the person who would bring God's blessings and favor back to Jerusalem."
before your face - "in front of you" or "to go ahead of you"
from their heart - This means the devil takes away their desire to believe the word of God.
and my words - AT: "and what I say" or "and what I teach"

metonymy.quote: A voice came out of the cloud, saying
metonymy.notes: A voice came out of the cloud, saying - AT: "God spoke to them from the cloud, saying"
reasoning in their hearts - AT: "thinking about individually" or "considering in their private thoughts"
in my name - This refers to a person doing something as a representative of Jesus. AT: "because of me."
in your name - This means the person was speaking with the power and authority of Jesus.

metonymy.quote: May peace be on this house
metonymy.notes: May peace be on this house - This was both a greeting and a blessing. Here "house" refers to those who live in the house. AT: "May the people in this household receive peace."

metonymy.quote: it will be more tolerable for Sodom than for that city
metonymy.notes: it will be more tolerable for Sodom than for that city - "God will not judge Sodom as severely as he will judge that city." AT: "God will judge the people of that city more severely than he will judge the people of Sodom."

metonymy.quote: Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida!
metonymy.notes: Woe to you, Chorazin! Woe to you, Bethsaida! - Jesus spoke as if the people of the cities of Chorazin and Bethsaida were there listening to him, but they were not.

metonymy.quote: But it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you
metonymy.notes: But it will be more tolerable for Tyre and Sidon at the judgment than for you - AT: "But because you did not repent and believe in me even though you saw me do miracles, God will judge you more severely than he will judge the people of Tyre and Sidon"
You, Capernaum - Jesus now speaks to the people in the city of Capernaum as if they were listening to him, but they were not.
in your name - Here "name" refers to Jesus' power and authority.
your heart...your soul...your strength...your mind - These all mean that a person must completely love God with all of their being.
your heart...your soul...your strength...your mind - These all mean that a person must completely love God with all of their being.
your heart...your soul...your strength...your mind - These all mean that a person must completely love God with all of their being.
your heart...your soul...your strength...your mind - These all mean that a person must completely love God with all of their being.
and heard his word - AT: "and listened to the Lord teach"
sanctify your name - AT: "may all people honor you" or "cause everyone to honor your name"
Let your kingdom come - "Establish your kingdom." AT: "We want you to rule over your people."

metonymy.quote: a house divided against itself falls
metonymy.notes: a house divided against itself falls - Here "house" refers to a family. AT: "if family members fight each other, they will ruin their family."

metonymy.quote: If Satan is divided against himself
metonymy.notes: If Satan is divided against himself - "Satan" here is referring to the demons who joined Satan in rebelling against God. AT: "If Satan and members of his kingdom are fighting among themselves"
by the finger of God - The "finger of God" refers to God's power.
When your eye is good - AT: "When your vision is good" or "when you see well"

metonymy.quote: Everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man
metonymy.notes: Everyone who speaks a word against the Son of Man - AT: "Everyone who says something bad about the Son of Man"

metonymy.quote: all the nations of the world
metonymy.notes: all the nations of the world - Here "nations" refers to "unbelievers." AT: "all people of other nations" or "all the unbelievers in the world."
your heart - Here "heart" refers to a person's thoughts.
says in his heart - AT: "thinks to himself"
the name of the Lord - Here "name" refers to the Lord's power and authority.
I have sinned against heaven - Jewish people sometimes avoided saying the word "God" and used the word "heaven" instead. AT: "I have sinned against God."
sinned against heaven - AT: "sinned against God"
God knows your hearts - AT: "God understands your true desires" or "God knows your motives"

metonymy.quote: than for one stroke of a letter of the law to become invalid
metonymy.notes: than for one stroke of a letter of the law to become invalid - The phrase "one stroke of a letter" means the smallest part of a letter. It refers to something in the law that may seem to be the least important. AT: "than for someone to remove even the smallest detail of the law."
my father's house - AT: "my family"

metonymy.quote: They have Moses and the prophets
metonymy.notes: They have Moses and the prophets - AT: "Your brothers have what Moses and the prophets wrote" or "They have heard what Moses and the prophets wrote"

metonymy.quote: If they do not listen to Moses and the prophets
metonymy.notes: If they do not listen to Moses and the prophets - "If they do not pay attention to what Moses and the prophets wrote"
this house - The word "house" here refers to the people living in the house or the family.
By your own words - AT: "Based on what you have said"

metonymy.quote: in the name of the Lord
metonymy.notes: in the name of the Lord - Here "name" refers to power and authority. Also, "Lord" refers to God.
he wept over it - The word "it" refers to the city of Jerusalem, but it represents the people who lived in that city.
from heaven - "from God." Jewish people avoided referring to God by his name "Yahweh." Often they used the word "heaven" to refer to him.
Caesar - Because Caesar was the ruler of the Roman government, they could refer to the Roman government by Caesar's name.
Caesar - Here "Caesar" refers to the Roman government.
in my name - AT: "claiming to be me" or "claiming to have my authority"

metonymy.quote: they will lay their hands on you
metonymy.notes: they will lay their hands on you - AT: "they will arrest you" or "they will grab you"
because of my name - AT: "because of me" or "because you follow me"
resolve in your heart - AT: "make up your mind" or "decide firmly"
because of my name - AT: "because of me" or "because you follow me"

metonymy.quote: they will fall by the edge of the sword
metonymy.notes: they will fall by the edge of the sword - "they will be killed by the edge of the sword." AT: "the enemy soldiers will kill them."

metonymy.quote: the kingdom of God is near
metonymy.notes: the kingdom of God is near - "God will soon establish his kingdom." AT: "God will soon rule as king."

metonymy.quote: my words will never pass away
metonymy.notes: my words will never pass away - "my words will never cease to exist" or "my words will never fail." AT: "what I say will surely happen."
This cup - The word "cup" refers to the wine in the cup. AT: "The wine in this cup" or "This wine."

metonymy.quote: which is poured out for you
metonymy.notes: which is poured out for you - "my blood, which is poured out in death for you" or "my blood, which will flow out of my wounds for you when I die." Jesus spoke of his death by referring to his body being broken and his blood being shed.
you will sit on thrones - AT: "you will work as kings" or "you will do the work of kings"
the rooster will not crow - Here, the crowing of the rooster refers to a certain time of day. Roosters often crow before the sun appears in the morning.
purse - A purse is a bag for holding money. Here it is used to refer to "money."
the authority of darkness - This refers to the evil ruler, Satan. AT: "the time of the ruler of darkness" or "the time when Satan is doing the evil things as he wants to do"
the word of the Lord - AT: "Jesus' words" or "what Jesus had said"
come into your kingdom - AT: "begin to rule as king"

metonymy.quote: into your hands I commit my spirit
metonymy.notes: into your hands I commit my spirit - AT: "I entrust my spirit to your care" or "I give my spirit to you, knowing you will care for it"
into the hands of - Here "hand" refers to power or control.
remembered his words - AT: "remembered what Jesus said"

metonymy.quote: and slow of heart to believe
metonymy.notes: and slow of heart to believe - AT: "your minds are slow to believe" or "you are slow to believe"

metonymy.quote: Why do questions arise in your heart?
metonymy.notes: Why do questions arise in your heart? - Jesus uses a question to mildly rebuke them. Jesus was telling them not to doubt that he was alive. AT: "Do not doubt in your minds!" or "Stop doubting!"
in his name - AT: "as his representative" or "with his authority"

litotes.quote: there will be no end to his kingdom
litotes.notes: there will be no end to his kingdom - The negative phrase "no end" emphasizes that it continues forever. It could also be stated with a positive phrase. AT: "his kingdom will never end."

litotes.quote: Do not lead us into temptation
litotes.notes: Do not lead us into temptation - AT: "Lead us away from temptation"

litotes.quote: without failing to do the other things also
litotes.notes: without failing to do the other things also - AT: "and to always do the other good things as well"

litotes.quote: not one of them is forgotten in the sight of God
litotes.notes: not one of them is forgotten in the sight of God - "God never forgets any of them"
it will not be forgiven - AT: "God will consider him guilty forever"

euphemism.quote: I have not slept with any man
euphemism.notes: I have not slept with any man - Mary used this polite expression to say that she had not engaged in sexual activity. AT: "I am a virgin."
had been bleeding - "had a flow of blood." She was probably bleeding from her womb even when it was not the normal time for it. Some cultures may have a polite way of referring to this condition.
his departure - "his leaving" or "how he would leave this world." AT: "his death."

doublenegatives.quote: nothing will be impossible for God
doublenegatives.notes: nothing will be impossible for God - The double negatives in this statement can be stated with positive terms. AT: "This shows that God can do anything." Elizabeth's pregnancy was proof that God was able to do anythingâ€”even enable Mary to become pregnant without her sleeping with a man.
not far from the house - The double negative can be replaced. AT: "near the house"
not stop - This double negative means "continues to."

doublenegatives.quote: nothing is hidden, that will not be made known
doublenegatives.notes: nothing is hidden, that will not be made known - AT: "Everything that is hidden will be made known"

doublenegatives.quote: If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father...he cannot be my disciple
doublenegatives.notes: If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father...he cannot be my disciple - Here, "hate" is an exaggeration to show how important it is to love Jesus much more than anyone else. AT: "If anyone comes to me and does not love me more than he loves his father...he cannot be my disciple" or "Only if a person loves me more than he loves his own father...can he be my disciple."

doublenegatives.quote: If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father...he cannot be my disciple
doublenegatives.notes: If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father...he cannot be my disciple - Here, "hate" is an exaggeration to show how important it is to love Jesus much more than anyone else. AT: "If anyone comes to me and does not love me more than he loves his father...he cannot be my disciple" or "Only if a person loves me more than he loves his own father...can he be my disciple."

doublenegatives.quote: any one of you who does not give up all that he has cannot be my disciple
doublenegatives.notes: any one of you who does not give up all that he has cannot be my disciple - AT: "only those of you who give up all that you have can be my disciples"

rquestion.quote: And why has it happened to me that the mother of my Lord should come to me?
rquestion.notes: And why has it happened to me that the mother of my Lord should come to me? - Elizabeth was not asking for information. She was showing how surprised and happy she was that the mother of the Lord had come to her. AT: "How wonderful it is that the mother of my Lord has come to me!"

rquestion.quote: What then will this child become?
rquestion.notes: What then will this child become? - "What kind of great person will this baby grow up to be?" It is also possible that this question was meant to be a statement of their surprise at what they had heard about the baby. AT: "What a great man this child will be!"

rquestion.quote: why have you treated us this way?
rquestion.notes: why have you treated us this way? - This was an indirect rebuke because he had not gone with them on the way back home. AT: "you should not have done this!"

rquestion.quote: Why were you searching for me?
rquestion.notes: Why were you searching for me? - Jesus uses two questions to mildly rebuke his parents, and to begin to tell them that he had a purpose from his heavenly Father that they did not understand. AT: "You did not need to be concerned about me."

rquestion.quote: Did you not know...house?
rquestion.notes: Did you not know...house? - Jesus uses this second question to try to say that his parents should have known about the purpose for which his Father sent him. AT: "You should have known...house."

rquestion.notes: Was it not necessary...glory? - Jesus uses a question to remind the disciples about what the prophets said. AT: "It was necessary...glory."

rquestion.quote: Was not our heart burning...scriptures?
rquestion.notes: Was not our heart burning...scriptures? - They use a question to emphasize how amazed they were about their encounter with Jesus. AT: "Our hearts were burning within us...scriptures."

rquestion.quote: Was not our heart burning...scriptures?
rquestion.notes: Was not our heart burning...scriptures? - They use a question to emphasize how amazed they were about their encounter with Jesus. AT: "Our hearts were burning within us...scriptures."

rquestion.quote: Why are you troubled?
rquestion.notes: Why are you troubled? - Jesus uses a question to comfort them. AT: "Do not be frightened."

synecdoche.notes: My soul...my spirit - Both "soul" and "spirit" refer to the spiritual part of a person. Mary is saying that her worship comes from deep inside her. AT: "My inner being...my heart" or "I...I."
My soul...my spirit - Both "soul" and "spirit" refer to the spiritual part of a person. Mary is saying that her worship comes from deep inside her. AT: "My inner being...my heart" or "I...I."

synecdoche.quote: He has thrown down princes from their thrones
synecdoche.notes: He has thrown down princes from their thrones - A throne is a chair that a ruler sits on, and it is a symbol of his authority. If a prince is brought down from his throne, it means he no longer has the authority to reign. AT: "He has taken away the authority of princes" or "He has made rulers stop ruling."
our feet - "feet" is used to represent the whole person. AT: "us"
my eyes have seen - This expression means, "I have personally seen" or "I, myself, have seen."

synecdoche.quote: Man shall not live on bread alone
synecdoche.notes: Man shall not live on bread alone - The word "bread" refers to food in general. Food as compared to God, by itself, is not enough to sustain a person. Jesus quotes the scripture to say why he would not turn the stone into bread. AT: "People cannot live on just bread" or "It is not just food that makes a person live."
bread - AT: "food"
our daily bread - Bread was in inexpensive food that people ate everyday. It is used here to refer to food in general. AT: "the food we need each day."
three loaves of bread - AT: "cooked food" or "prepared food"
for a loaf - "for a loaf of bread." AT: "for some food."

synecdoche.quote: Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts that nursed you
synecdoche.notes: Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts that nursed you - The parts of a woman's body are used to refer to the whole woman. AT: "How good it is for the woman who bore you and nursed you at her breasts" or "How happy the woman who bore you and nursed you at her breasts must be."

synecdoche.quote: Your eye is the lamp of the body
synecdoche.notes: Your eye is the lamp of the body - This has several figures of speech. The eye is a metonym for vision, which is a metaphor for understanding. The body is a synecdoche for a person's life. AT: "Your eye is the lamp of your life" or "Your vision is the lamp of your life." Since Jesus was saying something that is true of everyone, it can be translated as "The eye is the lamp of a person's body."
spoken in the ear - AT: "whispered to another person"

synecdoche.quote: I will say to my soul
synecdoche.notes: I will say to my soul - "I will say to myself"
to eat bread - "to eat" or "for a meal." Bread was an important part of a meal and is used in this sentence to refer to a meal.
he who will eat bread - The word "bread" is used to refer to the whole meal. AT: "who will eat at the meal."
David's son - "King David's descendant." The word "son" is used here to refer to a descendant. In this case it refers to the one who would reign over God's kingdom.
They also devour widows' houses - "They also eat up widows' houses." AT: "They also take away from widows all their possessions."

synecdoche.quote: But not a hair of your head will perish
synecdoche.notes: But not a hair of your head will perish - This refers to one of the smallest parts of a person to emphasize that the whole person will not perish. Jesus had already said that some of them would be put to death. So some understand this to mean that they would not be harmed spiritually. AT: "But these things cannot really harm you" or "Even every hair on your head will be safe."

synecdoche.quote: so that your hearts are not burdened
synecdoche.notes: so that your hearts are not burdened - AT: "so that you are not occupied with"
heard from his own mouth - AT: "heard it directly from him that he believes he is the Son of God"

parallelism.quote: his mouth was opened...his tongue was freed
parallelism.notes: his mouth was opened...his tongue was freed - These two phrases are word pictures that together emphasize that Zechariah was suddenly able to speak.

parallelism.quote: his mouth was opened...his tongue was freed
parallelism.notes: his mouth was opened...his tongue was freed - These two phrases are word pictures that together emphasize that Zechariah was suddenly able to speak.

parallelism.quote: in the house of...from among the descendants of
parallelism.notes: in the house of...from among the descendants of - These two phrases refer to the same thing, and emphasize that one who will save them is a direct descendant from King David.

parallelism.quote: in the house of...from among the descendants of
parallelism.notes: in the house of...from among the descendants of - These two phrases refer to the same thing, and emphasize that one who will save them is a direct descendant from King David.
our enemies...all who hate us - These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are repeated to emphasize how strongly their enemies are against them.
our enemies...all who hate us - These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are repeated to emphasize how strongly their enemies are against them.

parallelism.quote: his holy covenant...the oath that he spoke
parallelism.notes: his holy covenant...the oath that he spoke - These two phrases refer to the same thing. They are repeated to show the seriousness of God's promise to Abraham.

parallelism.quote: his holy covenant...the oath that he spoke
parallelism.notes: his holy covenant...the oath that he spoke - These two phrases refer to the same thing. They are repeated to show the seriousness of God's promise to Abraham.

Make ready...make his paths straight - This section is in the style of Hebrew poetry, which often repeats important phrases in similar words. "Make ready the way of the Lord" is therefore another way to say, "Make his paths straight." The main difference is the first indicates it happens once, while the second should continue to be done.

Make ready...make his paths straight - This section is in the style of Hebrew poetry, which often repeats important phrases in similar words. "Make ready the way of the Lord" is therefore another way to say, "Make his paths straight." The main difference is the first indicates it happens once, while the second should continue to be done.

parallelism.quote: To what then should I compare...they like
parallelism.notes: To what then should I compare...they like - Jesus used questions to introduce a comparison. AT: "This is to what I will compare this generation. This is what they are like."

parallelism.quote: To what then should I compare...they like
parallelism.notes: To what then should I compare...they like - Jesus used questions to introduce a comparison. AT: "This is to what I will compare this generation. This is what they are like."

parallelism.quote: what can I compare it to
parallelism.notes: what can I compare it to - This is basically the same as the previous question. Jesus used it to introduce what he would talk about. Some languages can use both of these, and some would use only one.

parallelism.quote: they should always pray, and not become discouraged
parallelism.notes: they should always pray, and not become discouraged - These two clauses have similar meaning which Jesus used to emphasize his point. Some languages have different ways of emphasizing. AT: "always keep on praying."

parallelism.quote: Permit the little children to come to me, and do not forbid them
parallelism.notes: Permit the little children to come to me, and do not forbid them - These two sentences have similar meaning and they are combined for emphasis. Some languages emphasize in a different way. AT: "You must certainly allow the children to come to me."

parallelism.quote: he is not the God of the dead, but of the living
parallelism.notes: he is not the God of the dead, but of the living - These two sentences have similar meaning said twice for emphasis. Some language have different ways of showing emphasis. AT: "The Lord is the God of eternally living people."

ellipsis.quote: Fear came on all who lived around them
ellipsis.notes: Fear came on all who lived around them - "All who lived around Zechariah and Elizabeth were afraid." It may be helpful to state clearly why they were shocked. AT: "Everyone who lived around them were in awe of God who had done this to Zechariah."
from the hand of - It may be helpful to restate "salvation" here. AT: "salvation from the hand of."
without fear - This refers back to the fear of their enemies. This could be stated. AT: "without being afraid of our enemies."
do likewise - "do the same thing." This refers back to giving food to those in need. It may be helpful to state this. AT: "give food to someone who does not have any."
to tell no one - "Do not tell anyone." This is an indirect quote. It refers back to the healing of the man. This can be stated. AT: "do not tell anyone that you have been healed."
because of the crowd - It is clear that the reason they could not enter was that crowd was so large that there was no room for them.

Seeing their faith, Jesus said - It is understood that they believe Jesus could heal the paralyzed man. This could be stated. AT: "When Jesus perceived that they believed that he could heal the man, he said to him."
question this - "discuss this" or "reason about this." What they questioned could be stated. AT: "discuss whether or not Jesus had authority to forgive sins."

easier to say - The unspoken implication is that one thing is "easier to say because no one will know," but the other thing is "harder to say because everyone will know." People could not see if the mans sins were forgiven, but they would all know if he would get up and walk.
love your enemies - This does not mean they were to only love their enemies and not their friends. This can be stated. AT: "Love your enemies, not only your friends!"
offer him also the other - It may be helpful to state what the attacker will do to the person. AT: "turn your face so that he can strike the other cheek also"
those who were sent - It is understood that there were the people the centurion sent. This could be stated. AT: "the people whom the Roman officer had sent to Jesus."
and from evil spirits - It may be helpful restate the healing. AT: "and healed them from evil spirits" or "and he set people free from evil spirits."
John the Baptist - AT: "Some say you are John the Baptist"
if not - AT: "if there is no person of peace there" or "if the owner of the house is not a peaceful person"

ellipsis.quote: Jesus was driving out a demon
ellipsis.notes: Jesus was driving out a demon - AT: "Jesus was driving a demon out of a person" or "Jesus was making a demon leave a person"
but on a lampstand - AT: "but they place it on a table" or " but they put it on a shelf"
and give to the poor - AT: "and give to poor people the money you earn from the sales"

ellipsis.quote: there will be five in one house
ellipsis.notes: there will be five in one house - AT: "there will be five people in one house"
kingdom against kingdom - AT: "kingdom will rise against kingdom" or "armies from one kingdom will attack armies from another kingdom"
famines and plagues - "there will be famines and plagues" or "times of hunger and diseases that kill many people"
No, nor does Herod - AT: "Even Herod does not think he is guilty"
to the hills - AT: "they will say to the hills"

quotations.notes: prophesied, saying - Consider natural ways of introducing direct quotes in your language. AT: "prophesied and said" or "prophesied, and this is what he said"

quotations.quote: the men said, "John the Baptist has sent us...we should be looking for?
quotations.notes: the men said, "John the Baptist has sent us...we should be looking for? - This sentence can be rewritten so that it only has one direct quote. AT: "the men said that John the Baptist had sent them to him to ask, 'Are you the Coming One, or is there another person we should be looking for?'" or "the men said, 'John the Baptist has sent us to you to ask if you are the Coming One, or if there is another person we should be looking for?'"

quotations.quote: the men said, "John the Baptist has sent us...we should be looking for?
quotations.notes: the men said, "John the Baptist has sent us...we should be looking for? - This sentence can be rewritten so that it only has one direct quote. AT: "the men said that John the Baptist had sent them to him to ask, 'Are you the Coming One, or is there another person we should be looking for?'" or "the men said, 'John the Baptist has sent us to you to ask if you are the Coming One, or if there is another person we should be looking for?'"
you say, 'He has a demon.' - Jesus was quoting what people were saying about John. AT: "you say that he has a demon" or "you accuse him of having a demon."
you say, 'Look...' - Jesus was quoting what the people were saying about him as the Son of Man.This can be stated indirectly as, "you say that I am a gluttonous man."
you say, 'Look...' - Jesus was quoting what the people were saying about him as the Son of Man.This can be stated indirectly as, "you say that I am a gluttonous man."

quotations.quote: to tell this to no one
quotations.notes: to tell this to no one - "not to tell anyone" or "that they should not tell anyone." This is an indirect quote. AT: "But warning them, Jesus told them, 'Do not tell anyone.'"

quotations.quote: that the Son of Man must suffer many things
quotations.notes: that the Son of Man must suffer many things - AT: "that people would cause the Son of Man to suffer greatly." This can also be translated as a direct quote as it is in the UDB.

quotations.quote: Being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, Jesus answered them and said,
quotations.notes: Being asked by the Pharisees when the kingdom of God would come, Jesus answered them and said, - AT: "The Pharisees asked Jesus 'When will the kingdom of God come?'"
"If we say, 'From heaven,' - Some languages might prefer an indirect quote. AT: "'If we say that John's authority is from heaven,"

quotations.quote: they answered that they did not know where it came from
quotations.notes: they answered that they did not know where it came from - AT: "They said, 'We do not know where it came from'"
The Teacher says to you - This begins a direct quotation where Jesus tells the disciples what they should say. The UDB renders this as an indirect quotation: "Our teacher says to show us."
that the Son of Man - This is the beginning of an indirect quote. It can also be translated with a direct quote as in the UDB.

abstractnouns.notes: in holiness and righteousness - These could be expressed as actions. AT: "to live in a pure way and to do what is right"
was righteous and devout - These abstract terms can be expressed as actions. AT: "did what was pleasing to God and obeyed God's laws."
preaching a baptism of repentance - The terms "baptism" and "repentance" could be stated as actions. AT: "preached that people should be baptized to show that they were repenting."
see the salvation of God - This could be stated as an action. AT: "learn how God saves people from sin"

abstractnouns.quote: salvation has come to this house
abstractnouns.notes: salvation has come to this house - AT: "God has saved this household"

inclusive.notes: Let us...to us - Since the shepherds were speaking to one another, languages that have inclusive forms for "we" and "us" should use the inclusive form here.
Let us...to us - Since the shepherds were speaking to one another, languages that have inclusive forms for "we" and "us" should use the inclusive form here.

inclusive.quote: so that we may eat it
inclusive.notes: so that we may eat it - Jesus was including Peter and John when he said "we." Peter and John would be part of the group that would eat the meal.
within us - The two men were speaking to each other. So the word "us" is dual inclusive for languages that make these distinctions.

hyperbole.notes: never left the temple - This is probably an exaggeration meaning that she spent so much time in the temple that it seemed as though she never left it. AT: "was always at the temple" or "was often at the temple."

hyperbole.quote: the log that is in your own eye
hyperbole.notes: the log that is in your own eye - This is a metaphor for a person's most important faults. A log could not literally go into a person's eye. Jesus is emphasizing that a person should pay attention to his own more important faults before he deals with another person's less important faults.

hyperbole.quote: wisdom is justified by all of her children
hyperbole.notes: wisdom is justified by all of her children - This is probably a proverb that Jesus was applying to this situation, because the people who rejected both him and John were not being wise.
nowhere to lay his head - "nowhere to rest my head" or "nowhere to sleep." Jesus is exaggerating in order to get across the point that he was not welcome anywhere to live.
they trampled on each other - This is an exaggeration in order to express how many people there were. AT: "they were stepping on each other."
a big tree - This is an exaggeration to make a point. AT: "a very large shrub."

hyperbole.quote: a camel to go through a needle's eye
hyperbole.notes: a camel to go through a needle's eye - It is impossible for a camel to fit through the eye of a needle. Therefore, it appears that Jesus may have been using hyperbole to mean it is extremely difficult for a rich man to enter God's kingdom.

hyperbole.quote: They will not leave one stone upon another
hyperbole.notes: They will not leave one stone upon another - This is a hyperbole to express how completely the enemies would destroy the city which was built of stones. AT: "They will not leave any of the stones in place."
All of the people - AT: "a very large number of people" or "almost everyone"
they compelled him - "They strongly urged him." The Greek word means to use physical force over an extended time, but it seems to be hyperbole. It took them some time and effort to persuade him.

you.notes: you - This refers to the people in the Old Testament who received God's Law. You could use the singular form of 'you' because each person was to obey it, or you could use the plural form of 'you' because all of the people were to obey it.
you may know - Jesus was speaking to the scribes and Pharisees. The word "you" is plural.
your - The word "your" is singular because God was speaking to the Messiah in the quotation.
I say to you - Jesus was speaking to the crowd so "you" is plural. Jesus used this phrase to emphasize the truth of the surprising thing he was about to say next.

you.quote: how long will I have to stay with you and bear with you?
you.notes: how long will I have to stay with you and bear with you? - Here "you" is plural. Jesus uses a question to scold the crowd. AT: "I have done so much and still you do not believe!"
Bring your son here - Here "your" is singular. Jesus is speaking directly to the father who addressed him.
I say to you - Jesus was speaking to the disciples. The word "you" is plural.

you.quote: who made me a judge or a mediator over you?
you.notes: who made me a judge or a mediator over you? - Jesus uses a question to teach the man. AT: "I am not your judge or mediator." Some languages would use the plural form for "you" or "your."
For when you go - Though Jesus is talking to a crowd, the situation he is presenting is something that a person would go through alone. So in some languages the word "you" would be singular.

you.quote: Struggle to enter through the narrow door
you.notes: Struggle to enter through the narrow door - "Work hard to go through the narrow doorway." Jesus is speaking about God's kingdom as if it were a house. Since Jesus is talking to a group, the "you" implied in this command is plural.
you will stand outside - Jesus was talking to a crowd. The form of "you" is plural. He is addressing them as if they will not enter through the door into the kingdom.
You cannot serve - Jesus was talking to a group of people, so languages that have a plural form of "you" would use that.
you also - Jesus was speaking to his disciples, so languages that have a plural form of "you" would use it.
you - The word "you" is singular because Jesus was speaking to the city. But if this would be unnatural in your language, you could use a plural form of "you" to refer to the people of the city.
you - The word "you" is singular because Jesus was speaking to the city. But if this would be unnatural in your language, you could use a plural form of "you" to refer to the people of the city.
I say to you - Jesus was talking to his disciples. The word "you" is plural.
you - Jesus was talking to his disciples. The word "you" is plural.

you.quote: to have you, that he might sift you
you.notes: to have you, that he might sift you - The word "you" refers to all of the apostles. Languages that have different forms of "you" should use the plural form.

you.quote: But I have prayed for you
you.notes: But I have prayed for you - The word "you" here refers specifically to Simon. Languages that have different forms of you should use the singular form.
When I sent you out - Jesus was talking to his apostles. So languages that have different forms of "you" should use the plural form.
Why do you seek - Here "you" is plural, referring to the women who came.
to you - The word "you" is plural. It refers to the women and the other disciples.
Peace be to you - "May you have peace" or "May God give you peace!"

hypo.notes: If he did that - This hypothetical statement explains the reason why a person would not actually mend a garment in that way.
If he did - Some languages might prefer, "if one did." This is an absurd situation that is not likely to actually happen.

hypo.quote: Which one of you...until he finds it?
hypo.notes: Which one of you...until he finds it? - Jesus uses a question to remind the people that if any of them lost one of their sheep, they would certainly go looking for it. Some languages have ways of showing that this is a hypothetical situation and not a story about a particular person who has lost a sheep.

hypo.quote: Which one of you...until he finds it?
hypo.notes: Which one of you...until he finds it? - Jesus uses a question to remind the people that if any of them lost one of their sheep, they would certainly go looking for it. Some languages have ways of showing that this is a hypothetical situation and not a story about a particular person who has lost a sheep.
what woman - This is a hypothetical situation and not a story about a real woman. Some languages have ways of showing this.

hypo.quote: There will be two women grinding together
hypo.notes: There will be two women grinding together - This is a hypothetical situation about what two women might be doing at the time. AT: "There may be two women grinding grain together."

hypo.quote: If I tell you, you will not believe
hypo.notes: If I tell you, you will not believe - This is the first of two hypothetical statements by Jesus. It was a way for Jesus to respond without giving them a reason to say that he was guilty of blasphemy. Your language may have a way of indicating that the action has not actually happened.

hypo.quote: if I ask you, you will not answer
hypo.notes: if I ask you, you will not answer - This is the second hypothetical statement.

gendernotations.notes: when all men - "when all people" or "when everyone"
good man - The word "man" here refers to a person, male or female. AT: "good person."

simile.notes: A generous amount...your lap - The order of this sentence can be reversed. AT: "They will pour into your lap a generous amount that they have pressed down and shaken together until it is spilling over." Jesus used the metaphor of a grain merchant giving a generous amount. AT: "Like a grain merchant who presses down the grain and shakes it together and pours in so much grain that it spills over, they will give generously to you."

A generous amount...your lap - The order of this sentence can be reversed. AT: "They will pour into your lap a generous amount that they have pressed down and shaken together until it is spilling over." Jesus used the metaphor of a grain merchant giving a generous amount. AT: "Like a grain merchant who presses down the grain and shakes it together and pours in so much grain that it spills over, they will give generously to you."
They are like - These words are the beginning of Jesus' comparison. Jesus is saying that the people of this generation were like children who were never satisfied with the way other children acted.

simile.quote: I send you out as lambs in the midst of wolves
simile.notes: I send you out as lambs in the midst of wolves - This means that there are people who could harm those that Jesus is sending out. The names of other animals could be substituted. AT: "When I send you out, people will want to harm you as wolves attack sheep."

simile.quote: I was watching Satan fall from heaven as lightning
simile.notes: I was watching Satan fall from heaven as lightning - Jesus used a simile to describe how God was defeating Satan when his 70 disciples were preaching in the towns.

simile.quote: then your whole body will be like when a lamp shines its brightness on you
simile.notes: then your whole body will be like when a lamp shines its brightness on you - Jesus speaks of people who are full of truth as if they are a lamp that shines brightly.

simile.quote: you are like unmarked graves that people walk over without knowing it
simile.notes: you are like unmarked graves that people walk over without knowing it - The Pharisees were like unmarked graves because they looked ceremonially clean, but they caused people around them to become unclean.

simile.quote: be like people looking for their master
simile.notes: be like people looking for their master - This compares the disciples being ready for Jesus to return to servants who are ready for their master to return.

simile.quote: It is like a mustard seed
simile.notes: It is like a mustard seed - Mustard seeds are very small seeds that grow into large plants. If these are not known, it can be translated with the name of another seed like it or simply as "a small seed."
for as the lightning appears - AT: "for as the lightning is visible to everyone when it appears and" or "for as the lightning appears suddenly"

simile.quote: whoever will not receive the kingdom of God like a child will definitely not enter it
simile.notes: whoever will not receive the kingdom of God like a child will definitely not enter it - God requires people to accept his rule over them with trust and humility. AT: "whoever wants to enter God's kingdom must receive it with trust and humility like a child."

123person.quote: Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear
123person.notes: Whoever has ears to hear, let him hear - It may be more natural in some languages to use the second person: "You who have ears to hear, hear."

123person.quote: when he comes in his own glory
123person.notes: when he comes in his own glory - Jesus was speaking of himself in the third person. AT: "when I come in my own glory."
the Son of Man - Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "I, the son of Man."
Son of Man - Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "I, the Son of Man."
the Son - Jesus was referring to himself in the third person.

123person.quote: Which one of you, if he has a hundred sheep
123person.notes: Which one of you, if he has a hundred sheep - Since the parable starts with "Which one of you," some languages would continue the parable in the second person. AT: "Which one of you, if you have a hundred sheep."
But first he must suffer - "But first the Son of Man must suffer." Jesus is speaking about himself in the third person.

distinguish.notes: who looked glorious - This relative clause gives information about Moses and Elijah. AT: "and they looked glorious."
my chosen Son - The word "chosen" gives information about God's Son. It is not saying that God has more than one son. AT: "my Son, whom I have chosen"

distinguish.quote: the ones who say that there is no resurrection
distinguish.notes: the ones who say that there is no resurrection - This phrase identifies the Sadducees as being the group of Jews that say that no one would rise from the dead. It does not imply that some Sadducees believed that there is a resurrection and some did not.

events.notes: He said to them - This was before the men actually went out. AT: "This is what he said to them" or "Before they went out he told them."

events.quote: bound up his wounds, pouring oil and wine on them
events.notes: bound up his wounds, pouring oil and wine on them - He would have put the oil and wine on the wounds first. AT: "he put wine and oil on the wounds and wrapped them with cloth."

merism.notes: Lord of heaven and earth - AT: "Master over everyone and everything in heaven and earth"

irony.notes: the wise and understanding - "from people who are wise and understanding." AT: "from people who think they are wise and understanding."

irony.quote: it is not acceptable to kill a prophet away from Jerusalem
irony.notes: it is not acceptable to kill a prophet away from Jerusalem - The Jewish leaders killed many of God's prophets in Jerusalem and Jesus knew that they would kill him there too. AT: "it is in Jerusalem that the Jewish leaders kill God's messengers."

irony.quote: ninety-nine righteous persons who do not need to repent
irony.notes: ninety-nine righteous persons who do not need to repent - Jesus was not saying that there really are any righteous people. He is referring to people who thought that they were righteous, but they were not. AT: "99 people who think that they are righteous and do not need to repent."

irony.quote: Prophesy! Who is the one who hit you?
irony.notes: Prophesy! Who is the one who hit you? - The guards did not believe that Jesus was a prophet. Rather they believed that a real prophet would know who hit him even if he could not see it. They called Jesus a prophet, but they wanted to show that he was not a prophet. AT: "Prove that you are a prophet. Tell us who hit you" or "Hey prophet, who hit you?"
Save yourself and us - The criminal did not really think that Jesus could rescue them from the cross.

parables.notes: Answering, Jesus said - Jesus answers the man by telling a parable. AT: "In response, Jesus told him this story."
the faithful and wise manager - Jesus tells another parable about how servants should be faithful while they wait for their master to return.

parables.quote: whom his lord will set over his other servants
parables.notes: whom his lord will set over his other servants - "whom his lord puts in charge of his other servants"
Blessed is that servant - "How good it is for that servant"

parables.quote: whom his lord finds doing that when he comes
parables.notes: whom his lord finds doing that when he comes - AT: "if his lord finds him doing that work when he comes back"

parables.quote: Why do you not judge what is right for yourselves
parables.notes: Why do you not judge what is right for yourselves - Jesus uses a question to rebuke the crowd. It introduces a parable about doing what is right before it is too late. AT: "You yourselves should discern what is right."
But Jesus said to him - Jesus begins telling a parable.
A certain man - This is the beginning of a parable. Introduce it in a way that is natural in your language. Some languages might say "There was a man who."

parables.quote: There was a certain rich man
parables.notes: There was a certain rich man - This is the beginning of another parable.

God forbid! - "May God stop it from happening!" or "May it never happen!" The people understood this parable to mean that God would remove them from Jerusalem because they would reject the Messiah. They strongly expressed their desire that this terrible thing would not happen.

personification.notes: God's wisdom said - AT: "God in his wisdom said" or "God wisely said"

sentences.quote: How much more valuable you are than the birds!
sentences.notes: How much more valuable you are than the birds! - This is an exclamation not a question. Jesus emphasizes the fact that people are much more valuable to God then birds.

sentences.quote: how much more will he clothe you
sentences.notes: how much more will he clothe you - This is an exclamation not a question. Jesus emphasizes that he will certainly take care of people even better than he does the grass.

sentences.quote: how I wish that it was already kindled
sentences.notes: how I wish that it was already kindled - This is an exclamation emphasizing how much he wants this to happen. AT: "I wish very much that it was already lit" or "How I wish that it had already begun."

sentences.quote: how I am distressed until it is completed!
sentences.notes: how I am distressed until it is completed! - This exclamation emphasizes how distressed he was. AT: "I am terribly distressed and will be so until I complete this baptism of suffering."

sentences.quote: you are freed from your weakness
sentences.notes: you are freed from your weakness - "you are healed from your disease." By saying this, Jesus was making it happen.

apostrophe.notes: Jerusalem, Jerusalem - Jesus speaks as if the people of Jerusalem were there listening to him. Jesus said this twice to show how sad he was for them.

hendiadys.notes: words and wisdom - AT: "words of wisdom" or "wise words"
